docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
Abilities represent a character's natural, untrained state, their raw potential. Each character is composed of the following abilities:

Ability Description Presence A combination of raw magnetism, artistic talent, and social insight Agility Reflects a character's quickness, reaction speed, and manual dexterity Strength A measure of a character's physical form and raw strength Awareness Represents a character's senses and insights Intelligence Indicates a character's education and critical thinking Resilience Mental and physical fortitude; resist injury and psychic burn Psi Represents a character's raw psionic ability

docs.title: Ability Scores
docs.text:
Each of your abilities have a number associated with it called an ability score, which has a natural range of 1 to 5. Cybernetic augmentations and psionic mutations can increase your ability score (up to +3), for a maximum augmented ability score of 8. Each of your ability scores must be at least 1, except for Psi, which is 0 if you are not playing a psionic character.

Ability Score Ability Level Description 0 Incapable Completely incapable, non-functional 1 Weak Underdeveloped, marginally capable 2 Below Average Less capable than most, often struggles 3 Average Human average, sufficient for most things in life 4 Exceptional Better than most, a serious contender 5 Peak Human The best of the best 6 Beyond Human Exceeds natural human limits 7 Superhuman Awe inspiring, breathtaking 8 Extraordinary Nearing limits of the animal kingdom, apex predator

Note: Ability scores above 8 are beyond player character capabilities and are provided to the GM to use as a basis for powerful enemies, such as constructs, and to show theoretical limits.

Ability Score Ability Level Description 9 Peak Animal The best of the best the animal kingdom has to offer 10 Construct Beyond the limits of the animal kingdom; artificial 11 Transcendent Passing beyond humans' ability to construct 12 Legendary Stories are told of such things, awe-inspiring 13 Unfathomable Almost beyond comprehension, unimaginable 14 Supreme Nearly breaking the laws of nature, mind-bending 15 Absolute Theoretical maximum, godlike

docs.title: Burn
docs.text:
Choose a burn for your character. Your burn represents a major event with such a negative impact that it made your old life untenable.

Burn Description Betrayed You were sold out or double-crossed by someone you trusted and had to run. Compromised Your secret identity was compromised, putting you at serious risk and forcing you to flee. Escaped You were held against your will, but you managed to escape. Experiment You were an unwitting test subject in a scientific experiment that went wrong. Exposed Your wrongdoing was exposed in a very public way, and you fled out of shame or fear. Financial Scam You fell victim to a scam and lost all your creds, which caused you to also lose your residence. Framed You were framed for a crime you didn't commit and had no choice but to run. Identity Swapped Your digital identity was swapped with that of a criminal and you ran. Lost it All You lost it all. Your family, your friends, your job, your residence. Everything. Gone. Left for Dead You were part of a tragedy with mass casualties. Somehow you survived. Made Enemies You did something to make some powerful people very upset with you, and you ran for your life. Reputation Loss Your professional reputation was destroyed by your enemies, leaving you with nothing. Witness You have evidence of a major crime like murder, coverup, or massive fraud.

docs.text:

Disillusioned You can no longer continue your old life with what you discovered in your burn. Honor Code You developed your own code of honor after the events of your burn, and you strive to uphold it. Hunted You are hunted by someone described in your burn, such as the megacorp where you worked. Owe a Debt You could not have come back from your burn without the help of someone to whom you now owe a debt. Radioactive Your old life is over and no one will touch you because they don't want to be associated with you. Reconstruct You are driven by the need to rebuild some semblance of your former power, wealth, or glory. Vigilante Your burn made you develop a moral code, and now you seek to punish those who break your rules.

docs.title: Character Creation
docs.text:
In this game, each player creates a character to play. As the player, you make all the decisions about your character, including their background, natural abilities, skills, and so on.

To create a character in GHOSTBURN 2325, follow the steps below.

docs.title: 1. Background
docs.text:
Choose a [[Backgrounds|Background]] for your character.

Your background describes who your character used to be and includes a culture, favored skill, and an additional benefit.

docs.title: Background Name
docs.text: Write the name of your background in the space labeled Background on your character sheet.

docs.title: Culture
docs.text: Your background gives you one Culture (Corporate, Milsec, Street, or Underworld). Write your culture in the space labeled Culture at the top of the character sheet.

docs.title: Favored Skill
docs.text:
Your background gives you one favored skill. Fill in the diamond symbol (◇) next to the skill name on your character sheet to indicate it as a favored skill, and write +1 in its skill bonus box.

Later on in the game when you spend XP to improve your character, it costs fewer XP to improve favored skills and to purchase signature tricks associated with your favored skills as compared to non-favored skills.

docs.title: Additional Benefit
docs.text: Your background also gives you an additional benefit which varies from one background to another. Your background may give you a piece of Gear, a cybernetic Augment, a Signature Trick, or even a bit of extra Luck. Write the additional benefit on your character sheet in the appropriate area.

docs.title: 2. Burn and Hook
docs.text:
Choose a [[Burns_and_Hooks|Burn and Hook]] for your character.

Your burn is a pivotal event in your life and helps explain why your character is no longer living the life described by their background. Your hook represents the lasting consequences of the burn.

Your background, burn, and hook should all tie together to show your character's story, like this:

I am a [Background] who was [Burned], and now I am [Hook].

For example:

I am a [Street Vendor] who was [Witness] to a murder, and now I'm being [Hunted] by the megacorp that wants to silence me.

Write your burn and hook at the top of your character sheet in the spaces labeled Burn and Hook, respectively.

docs.title: 3. Contacts
docs.text:
A contact is someone you personally know and with whom you are on good terms. You can call on your contacts periodically to see if they can help you. Contacts can provide information, goods or services, or even a place to sleep. You start the game with two contacts.

Medium - Your medium is the person who "discovered" you after you got burned. They used their power and connections to erase your digital identity on the Net, turning you into a ghost, someone who no longer exists in any database. They also put you together with the other ghosts in your crew. The GM will use your medium to offer you jobs, give you access to black market goods and services, and assist with other things you might need. The GM will tell you the medium's name so you can write it down on your character sheet.

Choose a Contact - Choose a contact that has the same culture as you. This person might be connected to your old life, they may have helped you when you got burned, or perhaps they even introduced you to your medium. Feel free to come up with a name and a few details about your contact. Write them down on your character sheet and share them with the GM.

docs.title: 4. Ability Scores
docs.text:
A character's ability scores reflect their natural abilities, such as their strength and intelligence.

Ability Name Description Presence Force of personality, social awareness, and artistic ability Awareness Physical senses, insight, and abstract thinking Agility Quickness, nimbleness, balance, and coordination Intelligence Education, reasoning, quick thinking, and general knowledge Strength Physical strength and general athleticism Resilience Bodily fortitude, health, and willpower Psi Raw psionic talent

The higher the score, the greater the ability. Natural ability scores range from 1 to 5, as shown below.

Ability Score Ability Level Description 1 Weak Underdeveloped, marginally capable 2 Below Average Less capable than most, often struggles 3 Average Human average, sufficient for most things in life 4 Exceptional Better than most, a serious contender 5 Peak Human The best of the best

You get 17 points to distribute between your abilities. Only one ability score can be set to 5 at character creation. The rest must be 4 or less.

If you want your character to be psionic, you must have a Psi score of 1 (the maximum at character creation). Otherwise, leave Psi at 0. This is the only ability score that can be 0.

Example Character (No Psionics) Example Character (With Psionics) Presence 1Agility 5Strength 4Awareness 2Intelligence 2Resilience 3Psi 0 Presence 3Agility 3Strength 1Awareness 3Intelligence 2Resilience 4Psi 1

docs.text:
Choose three skills, and write +1 in the skill bonus box for each. No skill may have a skill bonus be higher than +1 at the start of the game.

You do not start the game with signature tricks in these skills, but you can purchase them later in the game once you have earned XP.

docs.title: 7. Finishing Touches
docs.text: There are a few last things you need to do to finish creating your character.

docs.title: Luck Points
docs.text: You start the game with one [[Luck_Points|Luck Point]]. Write a 1 in the space labeled Luck Points on your character sheet. Later in the game, once you've earned XP, you can purchase up to two more Luck Points, for a maximum of three.

docs.title: Derived Characteristics
docs.text: Your Health Levels, Mesh Capacity, and Stabilization DL are derived from your other ability scores.

docs.title: Health Levels
docs.text:
Your hit points are based on your Strength and Resilience scores. Calculate the hit points for your Health Levels as shown below. When a halving would result in a fraction, round up.

docs.title: NPCs
docs.text: Non-Player Characters, or NPCs, are managed by the GM. They are contacts, enemies, and everyday people you might see on the street.

docs.title: NPC Traits
docs.text:
NPCs have three traits: [[[Keyword_Wits|Wits]]], [[[Keyword_Fort|Fort]]], and [[[Keyword_Threat|Threat]]].

[Wits] and [Fort] represent the NPC's smarts and toughness, respectively. They are each expressed as a [[[Difficulty_Level|Difficulty Level]]] and come into play when a player uses a trick on the NPC. Want to [[Skills_and_Tricks/Trick_Stealth_Core_Sneak|Sneak]] past a security guard? That targets the NPC's [Wits] to see if they notice you. Want to [[Skills_and_Tricks/Trick_Insight_Dodge|Dodge]] the guard's punch? That targets their [Fort] to see if you can avoid their fist.

[Threat] represents an NPC's overall competence and how much of a threat they pose. [Threat] is expressed as a bonus. When the GM rolls for the NPC, they add the NPC's [Threat] to get the result. [Threat] is used for all NPC rolls.

docs.title: NPC Health Levels
docs.text:
NPCs have four Health Levels, as described below.

An NPC's maximum hit points (Max HP) is equal to their [Threat] x 10.

For example, an NPC with a Threat of +1 has 10 Max HP, whereas an NPC with a Threat of +5 has 50 Max HP.

Health Levels Description Uninjured An NPC who has taken no damage (and is at full hit points) is [Uninjured]. No penalties. Fine An NPC who has lost hit points but currently has more than half their Max HP is [Fine]. No penalties. Hurt An NPC who has lost half or more of their Max HP is [Hurt]. NPC rolls have their DL raised by one. Defeated An NPC who has 10% or less of their Max HP is [Defeated]. The NPC is dead or nearly so; they cannot make rolls.

docs.title: NPC Skills
docs.text: NPCs have access to skills (and can have a bonus up to 3). As the GM, you are free to assign skills and bonuses to an NPC as you see fit. However, remember that, just like players, an NPC does not need a bonus to use a core trick and that a +1 represents Novice, +2 is Expert, and +3 is Professional. Some tricks cannot be used on player characters, which is noted in the trick's description if it applies.

docs.title: NPC Gear
docs.text: NPCs have access to gear, including armor, cybernetic augments, and weapons. However, NPCs only benefit from ability boosts granted by cyberware at half the rate and the bonus is added to Threat. For example, a cyberarm (Strength) 2 grants an NPC a +1 bonus to Threat.

docs.title: Agony
docs.text:
Cause: When a condition, effect, or injury causes you intense, unbearable pain, you are in [Agony].

Effect: All tricks have their DL raised by one and their outcomes [[[Keyword_Downgraded|Downgraded]]]. Taking painkillers diminishes the effect of [Agony]. When you take painkillers, tricks still have their DL raised by one, but their outcomes are not [Downgraded]. The benefit of painkillers lasts until the end of the scene.

Removal: When the source of the [Agony] is removed, you lose the [Agony] condition. If you are in [Agony] due to an injury, receiving Surgery or Cybernetic Installation, as described in the injury's Recovery entry, causes you to lose the [Agony] condition.

docs.title: Ally
docs.text:
Cause: When you achieve a Cool Success on certain specializations, you gain an [Ally]. If your trick was used on a [[[Keyword_Group|Group]]], one representative individual fills this role.

Effect: The target gains an [Attitude] of Friendly. As long as the target is an [Ally], they will help you. Beyond just following your instructions or fulfilling your requests, an [Ally] will take the initiative to provide assistance. They will try to protect you as best they can, use their skills and knowledge to your benefit, and warn you before you put yourself in danger or miss an opportunity.

Removal: If you (or any member of your crew) attacks your [Ally], the target loses [Ally]. When the scene ends, the target loses [Ally]\, but you can try to make them a [[[Keyword_Contact|Contact]]] (with the GM's approval). This requires a basic Presence roll with a DL of Severe (26). If you succeed, you permanently gain the target as a [Contact].

docs.title: Bewildered
docs.text:
Cause: When a skill action, condition, or effect leaves you deeply and utterly confused, you are [Bewildered]. This counts as and replaces the [[[Condition_Distracted|Distracted]]] condition.

Effect: Tricks used on you have their DL lowered by one and their outcomes are [[[Keyword_Upgraded|Upgraded]]].

Removal: At the start of your turn, you lose the [Bewildered] condition.

docs.title: Bleeding
docs.text:
Cause: When an attack, trick, or effect causes you to lose blood, you gain [Bleeding].

Effect: At the end of your turn, take 1 damage.

Removal: When you gain the [[[Condition_Stabilized|Stabilized]]] condition, you lose the [Bleeding] condition.

docs.title: Blinded
docs.text:
Cause: When an attack, condition, or environmental effect prevents you from seeing, you are [Blinded]. This condition replaces [[[Condition_Vision_Impairment|Vision Impairment]]].

Effect: You cannot see. All targets have [Concealment, Total] from you. Skills and tricks with the [[[Keyword_Visual|Visual]]] keyword have their DL raised by one and their outcomes [Degraded]. It is not possible to even attempt an action that is exclusively dependent upon sight, such as identifying the man in the bowler hat. You gain [[[Condition_Movement_Restricted|Movement Restricted]]].

Removal: When the condition or environmental effect that caused you to be [Blinded] is removed, you lose the [Blinded] condition. In rare cases, this condition is permanent.

docs.title: Break
docs.text:
Cause: When a a person or situation pushes you to your limits, you [Break] and can no longer control your actions.

Effect: You attack, flee, or break down on the spot. If you attack, you target what you perceive to be the source of your ire, which could be a person, place, or thing. If you flee, you attempt to escape that perceived source. If you break down, you fall [[[Condition_Prone|Prone]]] and pour out your emotions. If a group is caused to [Break], individuals from the group represent all three reactions. If a character caused the target to break, the target's [Attitude] towards that character drops to Hostile. If the target is [[[Condition_Compliant|Compliant]]] when they [Break], they lose [Compliant].

Removal: At the start of your turn, make a basic Resilience roll with a DL of Moderate (14). Success means you regain control and lose the [Break] condition. For NPCs, the GM should make a Threat roll using the NPC's Fort as the DL.

docs.title: Cognitive Impairment
docs.text:
Cause: When a condition or effect makes it harder for you to think, you have a [Cognitive Impairment].

Effect: Tricks that use Intelligence have their DL raised by one.

Removal: When the condition or effect that caused [Cognitive Impairment] is removed, you lose the [Cognitive Impairment] condition. In rare cases, this condition is permanent.

docs.title: Compliant
docs.text:
Cause: When a person or group is compelled to perform actions under duress, they gain the [Compliant] condition. This condition cannot be applied to player characters.

Effect: The Attitude of the [Compliant] person or group shifts to Hostile. They follow your instructions, even if they go against their own self-interests, but they will not put their loved ones in harm's way. They will not attempt to escape or retaliate as long as you remain in the [[[Keyword_Vicinity|Vicinity]]].

Removal: If a target suffers a [Break], they lose [Compliant]. Forcing the target to do worse and more dangerous things requires a basic Presence roll (GM's discretion), and Failure means the target suffers a [[[Condition_Break|Break]]]. Forcing the target to put their loved ones in harm's way causes them to automatically [Break]. If you or your crew attack the target, they suffer a [Break]. If you leave the [Vicinity] for more than one turn, the target automatically loses [Compliant] and flees or prepares to attack upon your return.

docs.title: Concealment, Partial
docs.text:
Cause: You are partly concealed, making it harder for you to be seen by an observer. It is possible to have [Concealment, Partial] to one observer and not another.

Effect: Attacks made against you by an observer to whom you have [Concealment, Partial] have their DL raised by one. Attempts to locate you through sight alone have their DL raised by one.

Removal: When you become fully visible to an observer or gain [[[Condition_Concealment_Total|Concealment, Total]]] to them, you no longer have [Concealment, Partial] to them.

docs.title: Concealment, Total
docs.text:
Cause: Your entire body, including your gear, is totally concealed and cannot be seen by an observer. It is possible to have [Concealment, Total] to one observer and not another.

Effect: When someone to whom you have [Concealment, Total] attempts to use a [Visual] trick on you, their DL raised by two and their outcome is [[[Keyword_Downgraded|Downgraded]]]. Attempts made by the observer to locate you through sight alone automatically fail.

Removal: When you become fully visible to an observer or switch to having [[[Condition_Concealment_Partial|Concealment, Partial]]] to them, you no longer have [Concealment, Total] to them.

docs.title: Confident
docs.text:
Cause: When you feel good about yourself and believe in your own abilities, you are [Confident]. This condition cannot be applied to player characters.

Effect: [[[Keyword_Social|Social]]] skills and tricks used on your have their DL raised by one.

Removal: When the scene ends or when something happens to ruin your state of mind, you lose [Confident].

docs.title: Confused
docs.text:
Cause: When a trick, condition, or effect makes it hard to think, you are [Confused].

Effect: When you use a skill or trick that has the [[[Keyword_Concentrate|Concentrate]]] keyword, raise the DL by one.

Removal: At the start of your turn, you lose the [Confused] condition.

docs.title: Cover, Full
docs.text:
Cause: Your body is fully behind a solid object, and you are in now way exposed, making it impossible to see you or make an [[[Keyword_Attack|Attack]]] against you. It is possible to have [Cover, Full] to one observer and not another.

Effect: Attacks made against you by an observer to whom you have [Cover, Full] automatically fail.

Removal: When you become fully exposed to an observer or gain [[[Condition_Cover_Partial|Cover, Partial]]] to them, you no longer have [Cover, Full] to them.

docs.title: Cover, Partial
docs.text:
Cause: Your body is partly behind a solid object and partly exposed, making it harder for you to be seen by an observer or struck by an [[[Keyword_Attack|Attack]]]. It is possible to have [Cover, Partial] to one observer and not another.

Effect: Attacks made against you by an observer to whom you have [Cover, Partial] have their DL raised by one. Attempts to locate you through sight alone have their DL raised by one. If you are hit by an attacker from whom you have [Cover, Partial], the damage is [[[Keyword_Reduced|Reduced]]].

Removal: When you become fully visible to an observer or gain [[[Condition_Concealment_Total|Concealment, Total]]] to them, you no longer have [Concealment, Partial] to them.

docs.title: Critical Condition
docs.text:
Cause: When you have sustained a [[[Condition_Life_Threatening|Life Threatening]]] injury and were subsequently [[[Condition_Stabilized|Stabilized]]] only to then fail your basic Resilience roll at the start of a scene, you enter [Critical Condition]. You can also gain [Critical Condition] as the result of Surgery or Cybernetic Installation that ends in critical failure.

Effect: At the end of each hour that passes, relative to you, make a basic Resilience roll with a DL of Severe (18). If you succeed, you gain [Stabilized]. If you fail, make a mark. If you accumulate more marks than your Resilience score, you advance to [[[Condition_Dying|Dying]]].

Removal: When you gain [Stabilized], you lose [Critical Condition]. Any marks accumulated from failed basic Resilience rolls are reset to zero.

docs.title: Deafened
docs.text:
Cause: When a skill, trick, or condition prevents you from hearing, you gain the [Deafened] condition. This condition replaces [Hearing Impaired].

Effect: You cannot hear. You are immune to sound-based attacks. Skill and tricks with the [[[Keyword_Vocal|Vocal]]] keyword have their DL raised by one. You are unable to use skills or tricks that have the [[[Keyword_Auditory|Auditory]]] keyword.

Removal: When the effect or condition that caused you to be [Deafened] is removed, you lose the [Deafened] condition. In rare cases, this condition is permanent.

docs.title: Death's Door
docs.text:
Cause: When you are reduced to half your Severely Wounded value (or less) in hit points, you gain the [Death's Door] condition. This condition follows and replaces [[[Condition_Wounded|Wounded]]] and [[[Condition_Severely_Wounded|Severely Wounded]]].

Effect: You gain [[[Condition_Movement_Restricted|Movement Restricted]]]. You are [[[Condition_Prone|Prone]]]. All skill actions have their DL raised by one. The first time you gain [Death's Door] during a scene, roll on the Injury Level Chart.

Removal: When you have more than half of your Severely Wounded hit points, you lose the [Death's Door] condition. You also lose the [Death's Door] condition if you advance to [[[Condition_Dying|Dying]]].

docs.title: Disfigured, Major
docs.text:
Cause: When a condition or injury dramatically alters your appearance in an unnatural way, you gain [Disfigured, Major]. This condition stacks with itself and with [[[Condition_Disfigured_Minor|Disfigured Minor]]].

Effect: Persuade tricks have their DL raised by one and their outcomes [[[Keyword_Downgraded|Downgraded]]]. Intimidate tricks have their DL lowered by one.

Removal: When the condition that caused you to be [Disfigured, Major] is removed, you lose the [Disfigured, Major] condition. If you gained [Disfigured, Major] as the result of an injury, receiving Surgery or Cybernetic Installation, as described in the Treatment entry of the injury description. causes you to lose [Disfigured, Major].

docs.title: Disfigured, Minor
docs.text:
Cause: When a condition or injury alters your appearance in an unnatural way, you gain [Disfigured, Minor]. This condition stacks with itself and with [[[Condition_Disfigured_Major|Disfigured, Major]]].

Effect: Persuade tricks have their DL raised by one. Intimidate tricks have their DL lowered by one.

Removal: When the condition that caused you to be [Disfigured, Minor] is removed, you lose the [Disfigured, Minor] condition. If you gained [Disfigured, Minor] as the result of an injury, receiving Surgery or Cybernetic Installation, as described in the Recovery entry of the injury description. causes you to lose [Disfigured, Minor].

docs.title: Distracted
docs.text:
Cause: When a skill action, condition, or effect causes you to become unfocused and momentarily lose track of what you were doing, you are [Distracted].

Effect: Skills and tricks used on you have their DL lowered by one.

Removal: At the start of your turn, you lose the [Distracted] condition.

docs.title: Drowning
docs.text:
Cause: When you are underwater and unable to breathe or hold your breathe, you are [Drowning]. If you are swimming and become [[[Condition_Unconscious|Unconscious]]], you automatically begin [Drowning]. If you are forced to go [[[Condition_Prone|Prone]]] while swimming, you begin [Drowning].

Effect: You lose [Prone] and gain [[[Condition_Movement_Restricted|Movement Restricted]]] and [[[Condition_Off_Guard|Off Guard]]]. All skills and tricks have their DL raised by one. At the start of your turn, take 5 damage and make a basic Resilience roll with a DL of Severe (18). If you succeed, you automatically [[[Keyword_Move|Move]]] [[[Keyword_Nearby|Nearby]]] towards the water's surface. If the water's surface was [[[Keyword_Far|Far]]] away, you are still [Drowning]. Otherwise, you break the water's surface.

Removal: If you break the water's surface, you lose [Drowning].

docs.title: Dying
docs.text:
Cause: When you are reduced to 0 hit points, you gain the [Dying] condition. This condition follows and replaces [[[Condition_Healthy|Healthy]]], [[[Condition_Wounded|Wounded]]], [[[Condition_Severely_Wounded|Severely Wounded]]], and [Death's Door].

Effect: You are [[[Condition_Unconscious|Unconscious]]]. Make a mark. At the start of your turn, make a basic Resilience roll with a DL of Hard (14). Success means you gain the [[[Condition_Stabilized|Stabilized]]] condition. Failure means you make another mark. If you accumulate more marks than your Resilience score, you are dead.

Removal: When you gain [Stabilized], you lose the [Dying] condition. You have 1 hit point.

docs.title: Emotional
docs.text:
Cause: A [[[Keyword_Social|Social]]] skill action can move you so deeply that you become [Emotional].

Effect: [Social] skills and tricks used on you have their DL lowered by one. This condition manifests as an emotional change that matches the tone of whatever triggered it. You might become angry, melancholy, reverent, nostalgic, excited, or cheery.

Removal: When the scene ends, you lose the [Emotional] condition.

docs.title: Entertained
docs.text:
Cause: When you witness something funny or enjoyable as the result of a trick, you are [Entertained]. This condition cannot be applied to player characters.

Effect: Your [Attitude] is raised one level.

Removal: When the scene ends or when something happens to ruin your entertainment, you lose [Entertained].

docs.title: Fine Motor Impairment
docs.text:
Cause: When you have difficulty doing things that use fine motor control, you have [Fine Motor Impairment].

Effect: Tricks with the [[[Keyword_Fine_Control|Fine Control]]] keyword have their DL raised by one.

Removal: When the condition that caused [Fine Motor Impairment] is removed, you lose the [Fine Motor Impairment] condition. In rare cases, this condition is permanent.

docs.title: Foggy
docs.text:
Cause: When a lingering haze fills the air, obscuring people and objects in the distance, it is [Foggy].

Effect: Without some kind of imaging enhancement like [[[Gear_Clearview|Clearview]]], it is impossible to identify targets at [[[Keyword_Far|Far]]] range (or beyond [Far] with a [[[Gear_Scope|Scope]]]) when it is [Foggy]. Targets who are [[[Keyword_Nearby|Nearby]]] have [[[Condition_Concealment_Partial|Concealment, Partial]]]. Targets who are [[[Keyword_Close|Close]]] are unaffected.

Removal: When the fog thins or dissipates in an area, it loses [Foggy].

docs.title: Healthy
docs.text:
Cause: When you have more than half your maximum hit points, you are [Healthy].

Effect: You are healthy.

Removal: Lose at least half of your maximum hit points.

docs.title: Hearing Impairment
docs.text:
Cause: When you have difficulty hearing due to a condition or effect, you have [Hearing Impairment].

Effect: Skill actions with the [[[Keyword_Auditory|Auditory]]] keyword have their DL raised by one.

Removal: When the condition that caused [Hearing Impairment] is removed, you lose the [Hearing Impairment] condition. In rare cases, this condition is permanent.

docs.title: Hidden
docs.text:
Cause: When you successfully use the Hide skill action, you gain the [Hidden] condition.

Effect: You are [[[Condition_Undetected|Undetected]]] and have [Concealment, Total].

Removal: When someone finds you, such as by using [[Skills_and_Tricks/Trick_Perception_Core_Search|Search]] or you reveal your position by attacking, stepping out of cover, or making noise, you lose the [Hidden] condition.

docs.title: Immobilized
docs.text:
Cause: When you gain the [[[Condition_Unconscious|Unconscious]]] condition, you also gain [Immobilized]. You can also be [Immobilized] by certain tricks or conditions or by being bound, such as with rope.

Effect: You cannot [[[Keyword_Move|Move]]].

Removal: When the condition that caused you to be [Immobilized] is removed, you lose the [Immobilized] condition. If you gained [Immobilized] as the result of an injury, receiving Surgery or Cybernetic Installation, as described in the Recovery entry of the injury description. causes you to lose [Immobilized].

docs.title: Incapable
docs.text:
Cause: When a condition, effect, or injury renders you unable to act, you are [Incapable].

Effect: You cannot take actions or make reactions.

Removal: When the condition that caused you to be [Incapable] is removed, you lose the [Incapable] condition. If you gained [Incapable] as the result of an injury, receiving Surgery or Cybernetic Installation, as described in the Recovery entry of the injury description. causes you to lose [Incapable].

docs.title: Inspired
docs.text:
Cause: When a trick or condition leaves you feeling like you're at the top of your game, you are [Inspired].

Effect: Skills and tricks you use have their DL lowered by one.

Removal: At the start of your turn, you lose the [Inspired] condition.

docs.title: Jammed
docs.text:
Cause: When a trick or condition uses electronic interference to temporarily prevent a device from functioning properly, it is [Jammed].

Effect: The device does not function while it is [Jammed]. If the device was moving of its own accord, it stops. If it was flying, it lands safely on the first available surface and stops. If you are remotely controlling when it becomes [Jammed], you no longer have access to the device and may not control it until [Jammed] is removed.

Removal: When the device is moved beyond the range of the signal that is making it [Jammed], it loses the [Jammed] condition. At the end of a scene, if a device is [Jammed], it loses [Jammed].

docs.title: Life Threatening
docs.text:
Cause: When you sustain an injury that requires emergency treatment, without which you could could die, you have a [Life Threatening] condition.

Effect: You need immediate medical attention. At the start of your turn, make a [[[Keyword_Basic|Basic]]] Resilience roll with a DL of Moderate (14). Failure means you take 3 damage. This stacks with [[[Condition_Bleeding|Bleeding]]].

Removal: Receiving Surgery or Cybernetic Installation, as described in the Treatment entry of the injury. causes you to lose the [Life Threatening] condition.

docs.title: Mouth Breather
docs.text:
Cause: When a condition, effect, or injury prevents you from breathing through your nose, you gain [Mouth Breather].

Effect: Stealth and Persuade tricks have their DL raised by one.

Removal: When you gain the ability to breathe through your nose again, you to lose [Mouth Breather].

docs.title: Movement Impaired
docs.text:
Cause: When a condition or injury makes it harder to move, you are [Movement Impaired].

Effect: It costs 2 AP to [[[Keyword_Move|Move]]] [[[Keyword_Nearby|Nearby]]] or use a trick with the [Move] keyword. Athletics tricks have their DL raised by one.

Removal: When the condition that caused you to be [Movement Impaired] is removed, you lose the [Movement Impaired] condition. If you gained [Movement Impaired] as the result of an injury, receiving Surgery or Cybernetic Installation, as described in the Recovery entry of the injury description. causes you to lose [Movement Impaired].

docs.title: Movement Restricted
docs.text:
Cause: When a condition or injury makes it nearly impossible to move, you are [Movement Restricted]. This condition replaces [[[Condition_Movement_Impaired|Movement Impaired]]].

Effect: It costs 3 AP to [[[Keyword_Move|Move]]] [[[Keyword_Nearby|Nearby]]] or use a trick with the [Move] keyword. You cannot use Athletics tricks.

Removal: When the condition that caused you to be [Movement Restricted] is removed, you lose the [Movement Restricted] condition. If you gained [Movement Restricted] as the result of an injury, receiving Surgery or Cybernetic Installation, as described in the Recovery entry of the injury description. causes you to lose [Movement Restricted].

docs.title: Mute
docs.text:
Cause: When a condition, effect, or injury prevents you from speaking, you are [Mute]. This condition replaces [[[Condition_Speech_Impairment|Speech Impairment]]].

Effect: You cannot speak, though you may be able to make grunts or other sounds. You cannot use tricks with the [[[Keyword_Vocal|Vocal]]] keyword.

Removal: When the condition that caused you to be [Mute] is removed, you lose the [Muted] condition. If you gained [Mute] as the result of an injury, receiving Surgery or Cybernetic Installation, as described in the Recovery entry of the injury description. causes you to lose the [Mute] condition.

docs.title: Off Balance
docs.text:
Cause: When a trick, condition, or effect makes it harder to stay on your feet, you are [Off Balance].

Effect: When you are [Off Balance] and attempt to [[[Keyword_Move|Move]]] or use a trick with the [[[Keyword_Physical|Physical]]] keyword, make a basic Athletics roll with a DL of Easy (8). If you fail, you do not perform the action and immediately fall [[[Condition_Prone|Prone]]].

Removal: If a lasting condition is the cause of [Off Balance], then you lose [Off Balance] when you lose that condition. Otherwise, you lose [Off Balance] at the start of your turn.

docs.title: Off Guard
docs.text:
Cause: When you are in a state of being unprepared for danger, you are [Off Guard]. Most people are [Off Guard] by default.

Effect: An [[[Keyword_Attack|Attack]]] made against you has its DL lowered by one.

Removal: When you observe immediate danger or are alerted to its presence, you lose the [Off Guard] condition.

docs.title: Prone
docs.text:
Cause: When you lay down on the ground or are forced down by a condition or an attack, you gain [Prone].

Effect: [Ranged] attacks made against you, except Point Blank Shot, have their DL raised by one. [[[Keyword_Melee|Melee]]] attacks made against you have their DL lowered by one. On your turn while [Prone], you may spend 1 AP to stand up., While you remain [Prone], you are [[[Condition_Movement_Restricted|Movement Restricted]]]. If you are swimming when forced to go [Prone], disregard the rest of this Effect and you begin [[[Condition_Drowning|Drowning]]].

Removal: When you stand up, you lose the [Prone] condition.

docs.title: Raining
docs.text:
Cause: When a steady rainfall makes it difficult to see and hear, it is [Raining].

Effect: Targets in an area where it is [Raining] have [[[Condition_Concealment_Partial|Concealment, Partial]]]. Tricks with the [[[Keyword_Vocal|Vocal]]] keyword have their DL raised by one.

Removal: When rainfall thins or stops in an area, it loses [Raining].

docs.title: Recovering
docs.text:
Cause: When you are still healing from an injury, you are [Recovering].

Effect: While you are [Recovering], tricks you use have their Difficulty Level raised by one.

Removal: At the end of the session, you lose the [Recovering] condition.

docs.title: Restrained
docs.text:
Cause: When you are unable to [[[Keyword_Move|Move]]] because something or someone is actively preventing you from doing so, you are [Restrained.

Effect: You are [[[Condition_Immobilized|Immobilized]]]. On your turn, you can spend 1 AP to try and escape by making a basic [Strength] or [Agility] roll (your choice). If an NPC has subdued you, use their Fort as the DL. If you are being [Restrained] by rope, handcuffs, or the like, the GM should set the DL, typically at Severe (18). If you succeed, you escape by slipping out or breaking free.

Removal: When you are released by whatever had you [Restrained], you lose [Restrained]. If attempt to escape and get a Success on your basic [Strength] or [Agility] roll, you lose [Restrained].

docs.title: Servile
docs.text:
Cause: When you unnerve someone so much that they will do anything to please you, they are [Servile]. This condition replaces [[[Condition_Compliant|Compliant]]].

Effect: As long as the target is [Servile], they will follow your instructions and look for other ways to please you. You can give them one task to complete, and they will do it as best they can, even if it takes days.

Removal: To maintain the target's [Servile] condition, you must pay them a visit at least once a day until the task is complete. Otherwise, they lose the [Servile] condition. You may verbally release them from the [Servile] condition at any time.

docs.title: Severely Wounded
docs.text:
Cause: When you are reduced to half your half of your [[[Condition_Wounded|Wounded]]] value (or less) in hit points, you gain the [Severely Wounded] condition.

Effect: You gain [[[Condition_Movement_Impaired|Movement Impaired]]]. All skill actions have their DL raised by one.

Removal: When you have more than half your [Wounded] value in hit points, you lose the [Severely Wounded] condition. You also lose the [Severely Wounded] condition if you advance to [[[Condition_Deaths_Door|Death's Door]]] or [[[Condition_Dying|Dying]]].

docs.title: Shaken
docs.text:
Cause: When a trick, condition, or effect leaves you momentarily shocked by what you saw or heard, you are [Shaken].

Effect: Skills and tricks used on you have their DL lowered by one. Skills and tricks you use have their DL raised by one.

Removal: At the start of your turn, make a basic Resilience roll with a DL of Easy (8). If you Succeed, you lose the [Shaken] condition. If you are still [Shaken] when the scene ends, you lose the [Shaken] condition.

docs.title: Speech Impairment
docs.text:
Cause: When a condition or effect makes it hard for you to speak, you have [Speech Impairment].

Effect: Skill actions with the [[[Keyword_Vocal|Vocal]]] keyword have their DL raised by one.

Removal: When the condition that caused you to have a [Speech Impairment] is removed, you lose the [Speech Impairment] condition. In rare cases, this condition is permanent.

docs.title: Stabilized
docs.text:
Cause: When you are the target of a successful First Aid roll, or you succeed on a basic Resilience roll to avoid Dying, you gain the [Stabilized] condition..

Effect: You gain 1 HP and lose the following conditions: [[[Condition_Bleeding|Bleeding]]], [[[Condition_Critical_Condition|Critical Condition]]], [[[Condition_Dying|Dying]]], [[[Condition_Traumatized|Traumatized]]], and [[[Condition_Unconscious|Unconscious]]].

Removal: After [Stabilized] takes effect on you, you lose the [Stabilized] condition.

docs.title: Stress
docs.text:
Cause: [Stress] is triggered by getting a Fade on certain tricks. You can have [Stress] from multiple sources at once, but multiple instances of [Stress] from the same trick do not stack.

Effect: At the start of your turn, make a [[[Keyword_Basic|Basic]]] roll using the trick that triggered your [Stress]. Use the DL identified in the trick's Fade outcome. Failure means you trigger the Glitch outcome of that trick.

Removal: You lose the [Stress] condition if you fail the [Basic] roll and trigger a Glitch. On your turn, if you have [Stress], you can try to improve the outcome by using an action to roll the trick again; if you get a Success or Cool Success, you lose the [Stress] condition. If you have [Stress] when the scene ends, you lose the [Stress] condition.

docs.title: Stunned
docs.text:
Cause: When a skill action, condition or effect causes you to have a momentary mental shutdown, you are [Stunned].

Effect: You are [[[Condition_Immobilized|Immobilized]]] and [[[Condition_Incapable|Incapable]]].

Removal: At the start of your turn, you lose the [Stunned] condition.

docs.title: Suffocating
docs.text:
Cause: When a condition or effect makes it almost impossible for you to breathe, you are [Suffocating].

Effect: At the start of your turn, take 5 damage and make a basic Resilience roll with a DL of Severe (18). If you fail, you fall [[[Condition_Unconscious|Unconscious]]].

Removal: When the condition that caused you to be [Suffocating] is removed, you lose the [Suffocating] condition.

docs.title: Suppressed
docs.text:
Cause: When enemy gunfire pins you down, making it harder to move and retaliate, you are [Suppressed]. A single target can only have one instance of [Suppressed] at a time. Multiple applications of [Suppressed] on the same target do not stack.

Effect: You gain [[[Condition_Movement_Impaired|Movement Impaired]]]. When you make an [[[Keyword_Attack|Attack]]], the DL is raised by one.

Removal: At the end of your next turn, you lose the [Suppressed] condition.

docs.title: Suspicious
docs.text:
Cause: When you sense that someone may be lying, hiding something, or mispresenting the truth, you are [Suspicious]. This condition cannot be applied to player characters.

Effect: If you have a [[[Keyword_Friendly|Friendly]]] [[[Keyword_Attitude|Attitude]]] it worsens to [[[Keyword_Neutral|Neutral]]]. [[[Keyword_Social|Social]]] skills and tricks used against you have their DL raised by one. If the person you are [Suspicious] of is using a [[Skills_and_Tricks/Trick_Deception_Disguise|Disguise]] or a [[Skills_and_Tricks/Trick_Deception_Forgery|Forgery]], you may attempt to see through it. To see through a Disguise or Forgery, the GM makes a [[Keyword_Threat|Threat]] roll for the NPC and uses the DL set by the outcome the player achieved on their Disguise or Forgery roll.

Removal: If the subject of your suspicions improves your [Attitude] to [Friendly], you lose [Suspicious].

docs.title: Traumatized
docs.text:
Cause: When you sustain an injury by rolling on the [[Sustaining_an_Injury|Injury Level Chart]], you gain the [Traumatized] condition.

Effect: All tricks have their DL is raised by one.

Removal: When you are [[[Condition_Stabilized|Stabilized]]], you lose the [Traumatized] condition. If you are still [Traumatized] at the end of the current scene, you lose the [Traumatized] condition.

docs.title: Unaware
docs.text:
Cause: When you gain [[[Condition_Unconscious|Unconscious]]] or [[[Condition_Stunned|Stunned]]], you also gain [Unaware]. You can also be rendered [Unaware] by other circumstances.

Effect: You are [[[Condition_Blinded|Blinded]]], [[[Condition_Deafened|Deafened]]], and [[[Condition_Off_Guard|Off Guard]]].

Removal: When you lose [Blinded] or [Deafened], you lose [Unaware].

docs.title: Unconscious
docs.text:
Cause: When you gain the [[[Condition_Dying|Dying]]] condition, you also gain [Unconscious]. You can also be rendered [Unconscious] by certain tricks or conditions.

Effect: You are [[[Condition_Immobilized|Immobilized]]], [[[Condition_Incapable|Incapable]]], [[[Condition_Prone|Prone]]], [[[Condition_Unaware|Unaware]]], and [[[Condition_Unresponsive|Unresponsive]]].

Removal: If you are [Dying], you must be [[[Condition_Stabilized|Stabilized]]] with at least 1 hp to lose the [Unconscious] condition. If another condition or effect caused you to become [Unconscious], and it has its own Removal, you must abide by it. If no other Removal is indicated, then at the start of your turn, make a base Resilience roll with a DL of Easy (8). Success means you lose the [Unconscious] condition.

docs.title: Undetected
docs.text:
Cause: If a person has not detected your presence, then you are [Undetected] by them.

Effect: When you attack a target for whom you are [Undetected], they are treated as [[[Condition_Off_Guard|Off Guard]]] for that attack.

Removal: When you are seen or heard by someone, you are no longer [Undetected] to them.

docs.title: Unresponsive
docs.text:
Cause: When you gain the [[[Condition_Unconscious|Unconscious]]] condition, you also gain [Unresponsive]. You can also be rendered [Unresponsive] by certain special attacks.

Effect: You are [[[Condition_Mute|Mute]]] and cannot communicate in any way.

Removal: When the condition that caused you to be [Unresponsive] is removed, you lose the [Unresponsive] condition.

docs.title: Vision Impairment
docs.text:
Cause: When you have difficulty seeing due to a condition or injury, you have [Vision Impairment].

Effect: Tricks with the [[[Keyword_Visual|Visual]]] keyword have their DL raised by one.

Removal: When the condition that caused [Vision Impairment] is removed, you lose the [Vision Impairment] condition. If you gained [Vision Impairment] as the result of an injury, receiving Surgery or Cybernetic Installation, as described in the Recovery entry of the injury description. causes you to lose [Vision Impairment]. In rare cases, this condition is permanent. If no other removal is specified, you lose [Vision Impairment] at the start of your next turn.

docs.title: Windy
docs.text:
Cause: When strong gusts of wind interfere with , it is [Windy].

Effect: When it is [Windy] and you use a Firearms trick to [[[Keyword_Attack|Attack]]] a target that is [[[Keyword_Far|Far]]] away (or beyond [Far] if using a [[[Gear_Scope|Scope]]]), raise the DL by one. Also, when it is [Windy] and you use the Athletics trick, [[Skills_and_Tricks/Trick_Athletics_Core_Throw|Throw]], raise the DL by one.

Removal: When the wind dies down, it is no longer [Windy].

docs.title: Wounded
docs.text:
Cause: When you are reduced to half your maximum hit points (or less), you gain the [Wounded] condition. this condition follows and replaces [[[Condition_Healthy|Healthy]]].

Effect: All skill actions have their DL raised by one.

Removal: When you have more than half your maximum hit points, you lose the [Wounded] condition. You also lose the [Wounded] condition if you advance to [[[Condition_Severely_Wounded|Severely Wounded]]], [[[Condition_Deaths_Door|Death's Door]]], or [[[Condition_Dying|Dying]]].

docs.title: Cybernetic Augmentations
docs.text: Characters in GHOSTBURN 2325 can get cybernetic augmentations installed in their body.

docs.title: Mesh
docs.text: You have an attribute called Mesh which represents the limit on how much cybernetics you can cram in your body. All characters have a Mesh of 10, plus their Strength score, plus their Resilience score. For example, a character with a Strength score of 3 and a Resilience score of 2 has a Mesh of 15 (10 + 3 + 2).

docs.title: Mesh Cost
docs.text: Cybernetic augmentations have a cost in creds, as well as a a Mesh cost. You add up the Mesh cost for all of the augments you have to determine the total Mesh cost. Then you compare that value to your character's Mesh attribute. Your Mesh cost cannot exceed your Mesh attribute.

docs.title: Cred Cost
docs.text: The cost in cred for each piece of cyberware is equal to (Mesh Cost x Cyberware Level x 10,000). Cyberware that does not have a level is considered level 1 for purposes of this calculation. For example, a Datajack has a Mesh Cost of 1, so it costs 10,000 cred. Wired Reflexes 3, on the other hand, has a Mesh Cost of 14 (and it's level 3), so it costs 420,000 cred (14 x 3 x 10,000).

docs.title: Damage Array
docs.text:
All weapons (including unarmed attacks made with the Brawl skill) express damage as a damage array.

A [Damage Array] holds three values separated by slashes, like this: 5/10/25. These values correspond to the damage dealt on a Fade, Success, or Cool Success, respectively. The first number is [Minimum Damage]. The second is [Normal Damage], and the last is [Maximum Damage]. See the Outcomes section under Making a Roll for more information on Fade, Success, and Cool Success.

For example, you draw your Ranco Firewalker heavy pistol and use Firearms (Single Shot) to shoot at the security guard. You make a roll and score a Fade. According to the outcomes for Single Shot, a Fade deals [Minimum Damage]. The damage array for your Firewalker is 9/18/45. Since the first number in the array is 9, you deal 9 points of damage to the guard.

docs.title: Firearms Damage
docs.text:
When you use a Firearms trick, such as Firearms (Single Shot), use the damage array provided for the weapon. For determining damage for Single Shot, [Minimum Damage] is equal to the weapon's Base Value. [Normal Damage] is its Base Value times two. [Maximum Damage] is its Base Value times five.

Minimum Damage Normal Damage Maximum Damage Base Value Base Value x 2 Base Value x 5 For example, a weapon with a Base Value of 5 would have a [Damage Array] of 5/10/25.

docs.title: Firing Modes
docs.text: Weapons that have multiple firing modes have a damage array for each mode. For example, a light pistol only has a damage array for [Single Shot], but a PX-90 rifle has three damage arrays, one for each [Single Shot], [Burst Fire], and [Full Auto]. The damage array for [Burst Fire] and [Full Auto] use an adjusted Base Value to produce a damage array with higher values because the represent a larger volume of rounds.

docs.title: Brawl Damage
docs.text:
When you use a Brawl trick, such as Brawl (Unarmed Strike), to make an attack, such as by punching your opponent, the [Minimum Damage] is equal to your Strength score. [Normal Damage] is your Strength score times two. [Maximum Damage] is your Strength score times five.

Minimum Damage Normal Damage Maximum Damage Strength Strength x 2 Strength x 5 For example, a character with a Strength score of 3 would have an [Unarmed] [Damage Array] of 3/6/15.

docs.title: Melee Damage
docs.text:
When you use a Melee trick, such as Melee (Melee Strike), to attack with a melee weapon, such as a club or knife. the weapon's damage is based on your Strength score, plus the melee weapon's Base Value. The [Minimum Damage] is equal to your Strength score, plus the weapon's Base Value. [Normal Damage] is [Minimum Damage] times two, and [Maximum Damage] is your [Minimum Damage] times five.

Minimum Damage Normal Damage Maximum Damage Strength + Base Value (Strength + Base Value) x 2 (Strength + Base Value) x 5 For example, a character with a Strength score of 3 is wielding a knife with a Base Value of 1. So, [Minimum] damage is 4, [Normal Damage] is 8, and [Maximum Damage] is 20. The [Damage Array] for this character is 4/8/20.

docs.title: Clearview
docs.text: [Clearview] is a quality that can be applied to goggles, helmets (with visor), video cameras, and cybernetic eyes. When [Clearview] is active, you ignore [[[Condition_Concealment_Partial|Concealment, Partial]]] that would normally be granted to targets because it is [[[Condition_Raining|Raining]]] or [[[Conditions/Condition_Foggy|Foggy]]].

docs.title: Folding Stock
docs.text: A [Folding Stock] is built into or attached to a firearm and helps reduce [[[Keyword_Recoil|Recoil]]]. It can be deployed or folded in combat by spending 1 AP. When deployed, your second [[[Keyword_Attack|Attack]]] with the same weapon on the same turn ignores [Recoil]. If you make a third [Attack], [Recoil] is applied. If a weapon with a [Folding Stock] is also [[[Keyword_Concealable|Concealable]]], it loses the [Concealable] quality while the [Folding Stock] is deployed. [Folding Stock] does not stack with [[[Gear_Gas_Vents|Gas Vents]]].

docs.title: Gas Vents
docs.text:
This [[[Keyword_Firearm|Firearm]]] includes [Gas Vents] which help reduce [[[Keyword_Recoil|Recoil]]]. There are two versions of [Gas Vents]: Gas Vents 1 and Gas Vents 2. Gas Vents 2 is an upgraded version and replaces Gas Vents 1; they do not stack.

Gas Vents 1 - Your second [Attack] with the same weapon on the same turn ignores [Recoil]. If you make a third [Attack], [Recoil] is applied.

Gas Vents 2 - Your second and third [Attack] with the same weapon on the same turn both ignore [Recoil].

For example, the PX-90 comes with [Gas Vents 1], and it is a Rifle, which means it has the [Recoil] trait. The first shot with the PX-90 using the [[[Skills_and_Tricks/Trick_Firearms_Core_Burst_Fire|Burst Fire]]] trick has a DL of Hard (20). The second shot with Burst Fire on the same turn also has a DL of Hard (20) because Gas Vents 1 causes you to ignore [Recoil] on the second shot. The third shot with Burst Fire has a DL of Severe (26) because [Recoil] takes effect and raises the [[Difficulty_Level|Difficulty Level]].

docs.title: Gunlink Grip
docs.text: A [Gunlink Grip] is built into or attached to the grip of a firearm. A [Gunlink Grip] provides an interface between the weapon and the user's [Gunlink] cybernetic augmentation. Without the [Gunlink] augment, the [Gunlink] provides no benefit to the person wielding the firearm. Further, a [Gunlink Grip] can be configured so the firearm is locked and unusable by anyone except for those with authorized biometrics.

docs.title: Laser Sight
docs.text: A [Laser Sight] is built into or attached to a firearm. When turned on, a [Laser Sight] creates a thin, barely visible beam of light that puts a colored dot (usually red or green) on the target, making it easier to hit. You gain a +1 [[[Keyword_Gear_Bonus|Gear Bonus]]] to Firearms when using a [Laser Sight].

docs.title: Night Vision
docs.text:
[Night Vision] is a quality that can be applied to goggles, helmets (with visor), video cameras, and cybernetic eyes. When [Night Vision] is active, you can see as well in the darkness as you can in the light. You ignore the effects of [Dark].

When you are exposed to a bright light while using [Night Vision], you are immediately [[[Condition_Blinded|Blinded]]]. If you disable [Night Vision], you lose [Blinded] at the end of your turn.

docs.title: Scope
docs.text:
A [Scope] extends the effective [[[Keyword_Optimal_Range|Optimal Range]]] of a [[[Keyword_Firearm|Firearm]]] and helps you hit distant targets. A [Scope] can only be attached to a Heavy Pistol or Rifle. When you use a weapon with a [Scope] to make an [[[Keyword_Attack|Attack]]], the weapon's [Optimal Range] extends to include the next farther [Range]. If the weapon's [Optimal Range] is already [[[Keyword_Far|Far]]], then a [Scope] extends its [Optimal Range] to include targets beyond [Far] range. This is the only way to make an [Attack] on a target at extreme distances beyond [Far] range.

For example, a Ranco .357 Equalizer has an [Optimal Range] of [[[Keyword_Nearby|Nearby]]]. Attaching a [Scope] to this weapon would mean [Nearby] and [Far] are both treated as being at [Optimal Range]. A Salvati Duro Carbine has an [Optimal Range] of [Far], so its [Scope] means a target at [Far] [Range] or beyond would be treated as being in [Optimal Range].

docs.title: Silencer
docs.text: A [Silencer] is built into or attached to a firearm. It reduces the muzzle flash and noise caused by firing the weapon. Attempts to notice gunfire from this weapon have their DL raised by one.

docs.title: Thermal Imaging
docs.text:
[Thermal Imaging] is a quality that can be applied to handheld devices, goggles, helmets (with visor), video cameras, and cybernetic eyes. When [Thermal Imaging] is active, the world around you is [[[Condition_Dark|Dark]]], but you can see patterns of heat visualized as bands of color (red, orange, yellow, green, and blue). People and animals, as well as machines that produce heat, like vehicles, produce heat signatures that can be easily detected with [Thermal Imaging]. Note that [Thermal Imaging] can detect heat through a standard wall, but the farther away and the thicker the wall, the weaker the signal.

When you are exposed to a bright light while using [Thermal Imaging], you are immediately [[[Condition_Blinded|Blinded]]]. If you disable [Thermal Imaging], you lose [Blinded] at the end of your turn.

docs.title: Underbarrel Flashlight
docs.text: An [Underbarrel Flashlight] is built into or attached to a firearm. When turned on, an [Underbarrel Flashlight] illuminates everything [[[Keyword_Nearby|Nearby]]] with a bright, white light, which eliminates the [[[Condition_Dark|Dark]]] condition from that area. Additionally, anyone in the illuminated area has difficulty seeing you, as the bright light obscures their vision. You have [[[Condition_Concealment_Partial|Concealment, Partial]]] against them.

docs.title: Health Condition Effects
docs.text:
You can only have one health condition at a time, and your health condition changes when your hit points drop below (or rise above) the one you currently have.

For example, a character that has max hit points (30 hp) gets shot in the back. They take 10 points of damage. This reduces their hit points to from 30 hp to 20 hp. Their current hit points are still in the [Healthy] range because the next level down, [Wounded], starts at 15 hp. If this character gets shot again and takes another 10 points of damage, they will go from 20 hp to 10 hp, and that will drop them down from being [Healthy] to being [Wounded].

Health Condition Hit Points Example Effect Healthy Max Hit Points 30 hp You are healthy. Wounded Half of Healthy 15 hp Tricks with the [Physical] trait have their DL raised by one. Severely Wounded Half of Wounded 8 hp You can only [[[Keyword_Move|Move]]] once per turn. Skill actions with the [[[Keyword_Physical|Physical]]] keyword have their DL raised by one. Death's Door Half of SeverelyWounded 4 hp You are [[[Condition_Prone|Prone]]] and can only move by crawling once per turn. All skill actions have their DL raised by one. The first time you gain [Death's Door] during a scene, refer to [[Sustaining_an_Injury|Sustaining an Injury]]. Dying 0 Hit Points 0 hp You are [[[Condition_Unconscious|Unconscious]]]. You gain Dying 1. At the start of your turn, make a [[[Keyword_Basic|Basic]]] Resilience roll with a Moderate (14) DL. Success means you gain the [[[Condition_Stabilized|Stabilized]]] condition. Failure means Dying increases by 1. When your Dying value is greater than your Resilience score, you are dead.

docs.title: Hit Points and Conditions
docs.text:
Your character's health is measured in hit points (hp) and is based on your Strength and Resilience scores.

All characters have a maximum number of hit points equal to (Strength + Resilience) x 5.

For example, a character with Strength 2 and Resilience 4 would have:

Step Example Hit Point Calculation 1 (2 + 4) x 5 = Maximum hit points 2 (6) x 5 = 30 3 30 hp Max

docs.title: Calculating Health Conditions
docs.text:
Calculate your health conditions as shown below. When dividing a score in half results in a fraction, round up.

Health Condition Hit Points Example with 30 hp Max Healthy Max Hit Points 30 hp Wounded Half of Healthy 15 hp Severely Wounded Half of Wounded 8 hp Death's Door Half of Severely Wounded 4 hp

docs.title: Stabilization DL
docs.text:
When your character is [Dying] or suffering from one of several other conditions, they need to be [Stabilized] by someone who can make a Medicine (First Aid) roll. Your [Stabilization DL] is the Difficulty Level used for those rolls.

Your [Stabilization DL] is based on your Resilience score, as shown below.

Resilience Score Stabilization DL 1 Extreme (32) 2 Severe (26) 3 Hard (20) 4 Moderate (14) 5 Easy (8)

docs.title: Sustaining an Injury
docs.text: In this game, combat is dangerous, and its effects can be brutal. If you take enough damage, it can result in an injury, an enduring effect which might be easily resolved, could require surgery, or may even lead to cybernetic replacement.

docs.title: Injury Roll
docs.text: The first time you drop to Death's Door in a scene, make an Injury Roll. Roll 2d10 and consult the Injury Level Chart below to determine if you sustain an injury. No matter how many times you drop to Death's Door in a single scene, you only make an Injury Roll once.

docs.title: Roll with +2
docs.text: Some extra dangerous attacks available to the GM indicate that if the attack drops a character to Death's Door and triggers an Injury roll, the roll should be made with a +2. This +2 modifier applies to your roll on the Injury Level Chart and your subsequent roll on the specific Injury Chart (Minor, Significant, Terrible, Grievous, or Massive).

docs.title: Injury Level Chart
docs.text:
Make your Injury Roll and consult the Injury Level Chart below to determine your character's injury.

Roll 2d10 Injury Level Effect 2-3 None You do not sustain an injury. You gain [Lucky]. 4-5 Minor Injury You are [Traumatized]. Roll on the Minor Injury Chart. 6-8 Significant Injury You are [Traumatized]. Roll on the Significant Injury Chart. 9-12 Terrible Injury You are [Traumatized]. Roll on the Terrible Injury Chart. 13-16 Grievous Injury You are [Traumatized]. Roll on the Grievous Injury Chart. 17-20 Massive Injury You are [Traumatized]. Roll on the Massive Injury Chart.

docs.title: Resist the Injury
docs.text:
If your Injury Roll was 4 or higher, it means you suffered an injury. However, your Resilience allows you to resist the injury.

Make a [Basic] Resilience roll with a Hard (20) DL. If you succeed, lower the Injury Level by one. If this reduces the Injury Level to None, then you do not sustain an injury.

For example, if you get an 11 on your Injury Roll, it means you have to roll on the Terrible Injury Chart. However, if you succeed on your [Basic] Resilience roll, the Injury Level is lowered by one from Terrible Injury to Significant Injury.

docs.title: Specific Injury
docs.text:
If, after making a [Basic} Resilience roll, you still sustain an injury, roll on the appropriate chart below to determine your specific injury. If you applied a +2 modifier when you rolled on the Injury Level Chart, you also apply a +2 modifier to this roll.

The charts below include a description of the injury, its mechanical effect, and the steps necessary for recovery. Medical science in the world of the GHOSTBURN 2325 has made such astounding advances that even the most critical of injuries can be treated so effectively that patients are fully recovered in a week's time.
