docs.title: Absolute Damage
docs.text: [Absolute Damage] is 1 damage. This is the absolute lowest amount of damage any [[[Keyword_Attack|Attack]]] can deal where the roll yielded a Fade, Success, or Cool Success.

docs.title: Admin
docs.text: You have [Admin] access to a device or system. You can perform all the same functions as an [[[Keyword_Operator|Operator]]], but you also have full control and can make changes, such as performing a shutdown, locking out users, disabling alerts, modifying configurations, and so on.

docs.title: Advanced Supplies
docs.text: A high-quality version of [[[Keyword_Supplies|Supplies]]] worth 1,000 cred (which are consumed upon use)

docs.title: Armor
docs.text:
If you're wearing armor when you take damage from an [Attack], the damage is [[[Keyword_Reduced|Reduced]]]. If your armor is rated against the [[[Keyword_Weapon_Group|Weapon Group]]] used to make the [Attack], the damage is [Reduced] again.

For example, say your character is wearing an Armor Vest, which is rated against Light Arms and Blades. If you are hit by an EZTech Punisher Lite (Light Arms) for its [[[Keyword_Normal_Damage|Normal Damage]]] of 10, your armor causes the damage to be [Reduced] to its [[[Keyword_Minimum_Damage|Minimum Damage]]] of 5. Since your armor is rated against the Light Arms Weapon Group, the damage is [Reduced] again to [[[Keyword_Absolute_Damage|Absolute Damage]]] of 1. If, on the other hand, you were hit by a Sterling Elite .45 (Heavy Arms) for its [Normal Damage] of 16, the damage would be reduced to its [Minimum Damage] of 8. Since your armor is not rated against Heavy Arms, the damage is not [Reduced] any further.

Armor Type Rated Against Weapon Groups Leather Jacket [[[Keyword_Bladed|Bladed]]] Armor Vest [[[Keyword_Light_Arms|Light Arms]]] Nanoweave Vest Light Arms, Bladed, [[[Keyword_Blunt_Force|Blunt Force]]] Hard Armor Light Arms, [[[Keyword_Heavy_Arms|Heavy Arms]]], Bladed Full Body Armor Light Arms, Heavy Arms, Bladed, Blunt Force

docs.title: Attack
docs.text: An offensive action taken against an opponent usually with the intent to harm.

docs.title: Attitude
docs.text: [Attitude] is an NPC trait. It represents how an NPC feels about a particular person. [Attitude] can be thought of as a spectrum with three values: [[[Keyword_Friendly|Friendly]]], [[[Keyword_Neutral|Neutral]]], and [[[Keyword_Hostile|Hostile]]]. Some tricks cause a target's [Attitude] to go improve or worsen.

docs.title: Auditory
docs.text: You must be able to hear to use this trick.

docs.title: Aug Bonus
docs.text:
Your cybernetic augments or psionic mutations can grant aug bonuses to specific skills (up to +3). For example, a pheromone pump grants a +1 aug bonus to Persuade.

Multiple aug bonuses do not stack, and only the highest gear bonus is applied. For example, if you have have a piece of cybernetics that gives a +1 aug bonus to Persuade and another that gives a +2 aug bonus to Persuade, only the +2 aug bonus applies to your Persuade rolls.

docs.title: Basic
docs.text: When the rules call for you to make a [Basic] roll, they indicate the skill or ability score to use and the [[Difficulty_Level|Difficulty Level]] for the roll. They also describe the consequence for getting a Success or Failure. Unlike most rolls in the game, a [Basic] roll has only two outcomes (Success and Failure), and the text only describes one of those two outcomes (because it is the only outcome that has a consequence attached).

docs.title: Bladed
docs.text: The [Bladed] weapon group contains the following [[Keyword_Weapon_Types|Weapon Types]]: Blade.

docs.title: Blunt Force
docs.text: The [Blunt Force] weapon group contains the following [[Keyword_Weapon_Types|Weapon Types]]: Club, Unarmed.

docs.title: Close
docs.text: Represents a very short distance between you and the target. For example, the target is [Close] if you are in the same room (like a living room or private office), if it would take only a few steps to reach them, or if you could reach out and touch them.

docs.title: Concealable
docs.text: A [Concealable] weapon or item is easily hidden on your person and can only be discovered with a [[Skills_and_Tricks/Trick_Perception_Core_Search|Search]] roll.

docs.title: Concentrate
docs.text: You must be able to focus to use this trick. Persistent loud noises, unpleasant smells, personal illness, and other odious effects raise the DL by one. If it is impossible to [Concentrate], the skill or trick cannot be used.

docs.title: Condition
docs.text: A [Condition] is a status that can be applied to characters. Each condition includes its primary cause and often suggests other possible causes, describes the effect the condition has on a person, and explains how the condition is removed.

docs.title: Contact
docs.text: A [Contact] is a person you know and who has a Friendly [[[Keyword_Attitude|Attitude]]] towards you. A [Contact] is someone who will help you (not necessarily for free) when you call upon them. A [Contact] is a permanent part of your character and they remain available to you as a resource from one mission to the next. You can call upon any given [Contact] no more than once per session.

docs.title: Control Deck
docs.text: A piece of hardware used to wireless control a device, such as a [[[Keyword_Drone|Drone]]]. Often used in conjunction with a headset or [[[Datajack|Datajack]]].

docs.title: Core Trick
docs.text: Each skill has one or more core tricks. For example, First Aid is a core trick of the Medicine skill. A core trick includes its own outcomes chart that tells you exactly how to interpret the results. This is done to provide a consistent and efficient play experience for common in-game situations, such as needing to to stabilize a friend who has just suffered a grievous injury in combat. You may use any core trick, even if you have no skill bonus in the associated skill. For example, if you have no skill bonus for Firearms, you can still use the Single Shot trick by rolling Agility.

docs.title: Counterattack
docs.text: A special kind of [[[Keyword_Reaction|Reaction]]] triggered by some tricks and allows you to immediately use a trick to [[[Keyword_Attack|Attack]]] the opponent that triggered it, even if it's not your turn.

docs.title: Crashes
docs.text: When a [[[Keyword_Vehicle|Vehicle]]] or [[[Keyword_Drone|Drone]]] [Crashes]. it collides with an immovable object and comes to a sudden stop. If the [Vehicle] or [Drone] was traveling at [[[Keyword_High_Speed|High Speed]]], it is totaled. If the driver was wearing a safety belt, they take 5 damage. Otherwise, they take 50 points of damage. At [[[Keyword_Moderate_Speed|Moderate Speed]]], a [Vehicle] takes 30 damage and a [Drone] takes 15 damage. A [Vehicle] driver takes 3 damage with a safety belt or 30 damage without it. At [[[Keyword_Low_Speed|Low Speed]]], the [Vehicle] or [Drone] takes 10 damage or 5 damage, respectively. A driver takes 1 damage with a safety belt or 10 damage without it.

docs.title: Cyber Rig
docs.text: A portable device with a keyboard and a [[[Keyword_Datajack|Datajack]]] used for illegal hacking.

docs.title: Damage Array
docs.text: Damage for a weapon or an unarmed brawl attack is expressed as a damage array, which is a set of three numbers, separated by slashes, such as 5/10/25. These are the [[[Keyword_Minimum_Damage|Minimum Damage]]], [[[Keyword_Normal_Damage|Normal Damage]]], and [[[Keyword_Maximum_Damage|Maximum Damage]]] values, respectively.

docs.title: Datajack
docs.text: A cybernetic implant used to directly interface with devices and systems, such as a [[[Keyword_Cyber_Rig|Cyber Rig]]] or [[[Keyword_Drone|Drone]]]. When you are jacked in, you gain the [[[Condition_Unaware|Unaware]]] condition.

docs.title: Disabled
docs.text: When a device, system feature, or cybernetic implant is [Disabled], it ceases to perform its function(s). A maglock no longer locks, a video camera no longer streams video, a cyberarm no longer moves, and so on.

docs.title: Downgraded
docs.text: When an outcome is [Downgraded], it moves down one level on the [[Outcomes]] chart. That is, a Cool Success becomes a Success, a Success becomes a Fade, and a Fade becomes a Glitch. A Glitch cannot be [Downgraded].

docs.title: Drone
docs.text: An unmanned flying device equipped with at least one video camera. A [Drone] can be outfitted with additional cameras and microphones for reconnaissance and weapons for combat. Some drones also include a small storage area which can be used to deliver a payload, reticulating arms for remotely manipulating objects, and other features.

docs.title: Enabled
docs.text: When a device, system feature, or cybernetic implant is enabled, it is functioning.

docs.title: Far
docs.text: Represents a long distance between you and the target. For example, the target is [Far] away if they are at the end of the block, on the other side of a stadium, or standing on a balcony five stories up.

docs.title: Fine Control
docs.text: You must be able to engage in fine motor control, (such as the type of control needed to tie your shoes or write with a pencil), to use this trick.

docs.title: Firearm
docs.text: A [Firearm] is a weapon that uses the Firearms skill. The following [[Keyword_Weapon_Types|Weapon Types]] fall into this category: Heavy Pistol, Light Pistol, Shotgun. SMG, and Rifle.

docs.title: Fly
docs.text: [Fly] works just like [[[Keyword_Move|Move]]] except you can move [[[Keyword_Far|Far]]] away with 1 AP.

docs.title: Fort
docs.text: This trait represents an NPC's fortitude, toughness, and strength. [Fort] is expressed as a [[[Difficulty_Level|Difficulty Level]]].

docs.title: Friendly
docs.text:
When an NPC has an [[[Keyword_Attitude|Attitude]]] of [Friendly] towards you, they are helpful and kind to you. When you use a [[[Keyword_Social|Social]]] trick on a [Friendly] NPC, lower the DL by one.

If the target's [Attitude] is [Friendly], it cannot be improved. If something causes it to worsen, it drops to [Neutral].

docs.title: Gear Bonus
docs.text:
Your weapons and equipment can grant gear bonuses to specific skills (up to +3). For example, a laser sight gives a +1 gear bonus to Firearms.

Multiple gear bonuses do not stack, and only the highest gear bonus is applied. For example, if you have have a piece of gear that gives a +1 gear bonus to Firearms and another that gives a +2 gear bonus to Firearms, only the +2 gear bonus applies to your Firearms rolls.

docs.title: Gift
docs.text: A gift is an item of value. A minor gift is worth around 500 cred, a regular gift is worth around 2,000 cred, and an expensive gift is worth 5,000 cred or more.

docs.title: Group
docs.text: This trick can be used on a group of people. Raise the DL of the skill action by one for every 10 members. If the trick uses [[[Keyword_Wits|Wits]]] or [[[Keyword_Fort|Fort]]] as its DL, use the highest amongst the group.

docs.title: Gun
docs.text: A weapon used with the Firearms skill, including pistols, submachines, rifles, and shotguns.

docs.title: Handling
docs.text: [Handling] represents how easy or difficult a A [[[Keyword_Vehicle|Vehicle]]] or [[[Keyword_Drone|Drone]]] is to control. [Handling] can have one of three values: Good, Average, and Bad. When you use Drive to make a precision maneuver with a [Vehicle] or [Drone], apply its [Handling] effect (if any). Good [Handling] lowers the DL by one level. Bad [Handling] raises the DL by one. Average [Handling] has no effect on the DL.

docs.title: Heavy Arms
docs.text: The [Heavy Arms] weapon group contains the following [[Keyword_Weapon_Types|Weapon Types]]: Heavy Pistol and Rifle.

docs.title: High Speed
docs.text: A [[[Keyword_Vehicle|Vehicle]]] or [[[Keyword_Drone|Drone]]] traveling at 100 kph or higher. When you are moving at [High Speed] and are called upon to make a Drive roll, raise the DL by one.

docs.title: Hostile
docs.text:
When an NPC has an [[[Keyword_Attitude|Attitude]]] of [Hostile] towards you, they are discourteous and unkind to you, and they might even [[[Keyword_Attack|Attack]]] you. When you use a [[[Keyword_Social|Social]]] trick on a [Hostile] NPC, raise the DL by one.

If an NPC's [Attitude] is [Hostile] and something causes it to improve, it moves to [Neutral]. If something causes it to worsen, the target stays at Hostile gains the [[[Condition_Break|Break]]] condition.

docs.title: Improvised Trick
docs.text: When these rules don't cover an action a player wants their character to perform, the GM can allow the player to make a roll and declare it an improvised trick. The GM is responsible for setting the Difficulty Level and determining the outcomes. The GM should feel free to work with the players to identify the outcomes, and they should be publicly shared with everyone at the table before the player makes their roll.

docs.title: Language
docs.text: You must be able to speak the same [Language] as the target to use this skill or trick.

docs.title: Light Arms
docs.text: The [Light Arms] weapon group contains the following [[Keyword_Weapon_Types|Weapon Types]]: Light Pistol, Shotgun, and SMG.

docs.title: Location
docs.text: A specific, definable place in the world that serves some significance, such as the home of a witness, the destination of a suspicious person, or the crew's hideout.

docs.title: Low Speed
docs.text: A [[[Keyword_Vehicle|Vehicle]]] or [[[Keyword_Drone|Drone]]] traveling at 25 kph or lower. When you are moving at [Low Speed] and are called upon to make a Drive roll, lower the DL by one.

docs.title: Luck Bonus
docs.text: Before you [[Making_a_Roll|make a roll]], you can spend a [[[Luck_Points|Luck Point]]] to get a +2 Luck Bonus to your roll result. If the roll uses one of your Favored Skills, you get a +3 Luck Bonus instead.

docs.title: Lucky
docs.text: When a Cool Success or another effect makes you [Lucky], you recover 1 [[Luck_Points|Luck Point]].

docs.title: Manipulator Arm
docs.text: A [[[Keyword_Drone|Drone]]] can be outfitted with a [Manipulator Arm] and accompanying hand. The [Manipulator Arm] is capable of [[[Keyword_Fine_Control|Fine Control]]].

docs.title: Maximum Damage
docs.text: In a [[[Keyword_Damage_Array|Damage Array]]], the last number listed is the [Maximum Damage] value. This number is 5x the [[[Keyword_Minimum_Damage|Minimum Damage]]] value. For example, in the [Damage Array], 5/10/25, the 25 is the [Maximum Damage] value.

docs.title: Melee
docs.text: An [[[Keyword_Attack|Attack]]] made using a [Melee] weapon, such as a club, knife, sword, or cyberclaws, against an opponent who is [[[Keyword_Close|Close]]] to you.

docs.title: Minimum Damage
docs.text: In a [[[Keyword_Damage_Array|Damage Array]]], the first number listed is the [Minimum Damage] value, also known as base damage. For example, in the [Damage Array], 5/10/25, the 5 is the [Minimum Damage] value.

docs.title: Moderate Speed
docs.text: A [[[Keyword_Vehicle|Vehicle]]] or [[[Keyword_Drone|Drone]]] traveling between 25 kph and 100 kph

docs.title: Move
docs.text: When you use [Move], you spend 1 AP per range increment you want to go. For example, to go from the kitchen to the living room is [[[Keyword_Close|Close]]] to [[[Keyword_Nearby|Nearby]]] so that is 1 AP. To go from the kitchen to the outside and across the street is [Close] to [Nearby] (1 AP) and then [Nearby] to [[[Keyword_Far|far]]] (1 AP), so that is 2 AP.

docs.title: Nearby
docs.text: Represents a short distance between you and the target. For example, the target is [Nearby] if they are sitting on the other side of the cafeteria, standing across the street. or are in another car three lanes over from you on the freeway.

docs.title: Neutral
docs.text:
When an NPC has an [[[Keyword_Attitude|Attitude]]] of [Neutral] towards you, they are ambivalent towards you. They are willing to do business with you and will engage you in small talk, but they are not interested in doing you any favors.

If an NPC's [Attitude] is [Neutral] and it improves, it moves to [Friendly]. If it worsens, it moves to [Hostile].

docs.title: Normal Damage
docs.text: In a [[[Keyword_Damage_Array|Damage Array]]], the middle number listed is the [Normal Damage] value. This number is 2 times the [[[Keyword_Minimum_Damage|Minimum Damage]]] value. For example, in the [Damage Array], 5/10/25, the 10 is the [Normal Damage] value.

docs.title: One Hand
docs.text: You must use at least one hand.

docs.title: Operator
docs.text: You have [Operator] access to a device or system. You can perform basic functions as they are designed to be used, such as seeing through a video camera or changing the text on a digital sign.

docs.title: Opposed
docs.text:
This trick uses an [Opposed] roll to determine the outcome instead of the standard resolution process.

You roll just like you normally do. The GM rolls 2d10 and adds the NPC's [[[Keyword_Threat|Threat]]] bonus. Compare your result to the GM's result. If your result is 4 or more higher than the GM's roll, it's a Cool Success. If you get 1-3 higher than the GM's roll, it is a Success. If your result is equal to the GM's roll, it's a Fade. Lower than the GM's roll and it's a Glitch.

docs.title: Optimal Range
docs.text: A [[[Keyword_Firearm|Firearm]]] has an attribute called [Optimal Range]. A weapon's [Optimal Range] is one of the [[[Keyword_Range|Range]]] values: [[[Keyword_Close|Close]]], [[[Keyword_Nearby|Nearby]]], and [[[Keyword_Far|Far]]]. If you make an [[[Keyword_Attack|Attack]]] against a target at a [Range] other than the [Optimal Range], raise the DL by one for each range increment the target is away from the [Optimal Range]. For example, if your weapon has an [Optimal Range] of [Far], and you try to hit a target that is [Nearby], the DL is raised by one. To hit a target that is [Close] would mean the DL is raised by two.

docs.title: Physical
docs.text: When you use this trick, you physically interact with the world.

docs.title: Range
docs.text: This trick is affected by the distance between you and the target. There are three types of [Range]: [[[Keyword_Close|Close]]], [[[Keyword_Nearby|Nearby]]], and [[[Keyword_Far|Far]]].

docs.title: Reaction
docs.text: This trick is used in response to a trigger defined in its description. When the condition for the trigger occurs, you may use this trick even if it's not your turn. [Reaction] actions are free and do not have an AP cost. However, you can only use a number of [Reaction] actions each turn equal to your Agility score.

docs.title: Recoil
docs.text:
A [[[Keyword_Firearm|Firearm]]] with [Recoil] is more difficult to shoot multiple times on the same turn. When you use a weapon with [Recoil], every [[[Keyword_Attack|Attack]]] you make beyond the first with the same weapon on the same turn has its [[Difficulty_Level|Difficulty Level]] raised by one. This DL increase is cumulative. [Recoil] is a [[[Keyword_Weapon_Types|Weapon Type]]] characteristic and is found on Heavy Pistols, Rifles, Shotguns, and SMGs.

For example, the Desert Viper is a Heavy Pistol, which means it has the [Recoil] trait. The first shot with the Desert Viper using the [[Skills_and_Tricks/Trick_Firearms_Core_Single_Shot|Single Shot]] trick has a DL of Moderate (14). The second shot (with Single Shot) on the same turn has a DL of Hard (20), and the third shot has a DL of Severe (26).

docs.title: Reduced
docs.text:
To determine [Reduced] damage, use the next worse value from the weapon's [[[Damage_Array|Damage Array]]] compared to the damage generated by the outcome of the roll. [Reduced] damage cannot be lower than 1.

In other words, [[[Keyword_Maximum_Damage|Maximum Damage]]] is [Reduced] to [[[Keyword_Normal_Damage|Normal Damage]]], [Normal Damage] is [Reduced] to [[[Keyword_Minimum_Damage|Minimum Damage]]], and [Minimum Damage] is [Reduced] to [[[Keyword_Absolute_Damage|Absolute Damage]]].

docs.title: Secret
docs.text: Some tricks give you a [Secret] when you roll a Cool Success. A [Secret] has a few uses. First, it can be used to obtain a piece of important information related to your roll. If the GM has information to share that would satisfy the [Secret], they can offer it to you immediately. However, you can choose to bank the [Secret] instead and spend it later. A [Secret] may be spent at any time to ask the GM one Yes/No question related to the topic or context of your original roll. The GM must answer truthfully, though they may ask you to rephrase the question. Last, you may spend a [Secret] to lower the DL of any roll regardless of whether it is related to your original roll or not.

docs.title: Security
docs.text: [Security] is a measure of how secure something is. It can be used to define the difficulty of hacking a device or system, but it can also refer to the overall defense posture of a defined area, like an office building or a region of airspace. [Security] is expressed as a [[Difficulty_Level|Difficulty Level]]. Retail is Easy (8), Small Corp Grade is Moderate (14), Middle Corp Grade is Hard (20), Megacorp Grade is Severe (26), and Milsec Grade is Extreme (32).

docs.title: Security Alert
docs.text:
A [Security Alert] is issued when an intruder is detected by a device, system, or person, such as a guard calling in an alert.

In the case of a device or system, a [Security Alert] is issued when a hacker is detected. It forcibly dumps the user that triggered the [Security Alert] and notifies the [[[Keyword_Admin|Admin]]], as well as possibly executing a lockdown process and reporting the user's physical location to the appropriate security personnel.

When an intruder is detected at a physical location, the response varies based on its defense capabilities. A retail store will likely just autodial local law enforcement, whereas a megacorp is sure to have an array of resources and techniques it can choose from when forming its response.

docs.title: Signature Trick
docs.text: Signature tricks are specialized uses of your skills They represent advanced techniques that a person could not reasonably intuit their way through. They require special training and practice. Signature tricks work just like core tricks except you can only use a signature trick if your character has learned it. New characters start the game with two signature tricks selected during character creation. You can learn new signature tricks by purchasing them with XP.

docs.title: Skill Bonus
docs.text: Each of your skills can have a skill bonus (up to +3). Add your skill bonus to your roll when you use a trick governed by that skill. New characters start the game with a +1 bonus to a few skills. Later, once you've played the game and been award some experience points (XP), you can spend those points to pick up a +1 bonus in a new skill or increase an existing bonus (up to +3). This is covered in the Experience Points section of these rules.

docs.title: Small Item
docs.text: Represents an item small enough to fit in the palm of your hand, such as a ring, wristwatch, or data disk.

docs.title: Social
docs.text: This trick is used to interact with people. Unless otherwise indicated, you must be [[[Keyword_Close|Close]]] to your opponent to use a [Social] trick on them.

docs.title: Spray
docs.text:
When you make an [[[Keyword_Attack|Attack]]] using [[Skills_and_Tricks/Trick_Firearms_Core_Burst_Fire|Burst Fire]] or [[Skills_and_Tricks/Trick_Firearms_Core_Full_Auto|Full Auto]], you can use [Spray] to hit multiple targets that are [[[Keyword_Close|Close]]] to one another. Burst Fire can be used to hit one additional target (two total), and Full Auto can be used to hit up to four additional targets (five total). When you use [Spray], divide the damage equally between the targets. If the damage cannot be divided equally, any remainder is lost.

For example, you use Burst Fire to make an [Attack] with your Uzog MK-9 SMG. You opt to use [Spray] because there are two targets standing [Close] to one another. You make your Firearms roll to use Burst Fire and score a Fade, which deals [[[Keyword_Minimum_Damage|Minimum Damage]]]. The Uzog's [[[Damage_Array|Damage Array]]] for Burst Fire is 10/20/50, so the [Minimum Damage] is 10. This number is divided evenly between the two targets, so they each take 5 damage.

docs.title: Spread
docs.text:
When you make an [[[Keyword_Attack|Attack]]] with a shotgun, it uses [Spread] to hit multiple targets that are [[[Keyword_Close|Close]]] to one another. To determine which targets are hit, first identify the primary target. Then, look for additional targets that are [Close] to the primary and which are not behind [[[Condition_Cover_Full|Cover, Full]]] or [[[Condition_Cover_Partial|Cover, Partial]]] (including being behind other people). [Spread] can affect up to two additional targets, and you cannot choose to avoid hitting them. If the outcome of the [Attack] damage to the primary target, it deals [[[Keyword_Reduced|Reduced]]]] damage to each additional target as well. You cannot choose to avoid hitting additional targets.

Also, a weapon with [Spread] cannot be used to [Attack] targets at [[[Keyword_Far|Far]]] range.

For example, you use a Graham H6 shotgun to make an [Attack] against a target. There are two additional targets standing [Close] to the first (primary) target. You make your Firearms roll to use [[Skills_and_Tricks/Trick_Firearms_Core_Single_Shot|Single Shot]] and score a Success, which deals [[[Keyword_Normal_Damage|Normal Damage]]]. The H6's [[[Damage_Array|Damage Array]]] for Single Shot is 9/18/45, so the [Normal Damage] is 18. The primary target takes 18 points of damage. The two additional targets take damage from the next step down on the [Damage Array], which is [Minimum Damage]. The H6's [Minimum Damage] is 9, so the two additional targets each take 9 points of damage.

docs.title: Stability
docs.text: This trait represents the overall balance and mass of a [[Keyword_Vehicle|Vehicle]] and is used to resist being pushed around on the road. [Stability] is expressed as a [[Difficulty_Level|Difficulty Level]].

docs.title: Stabilization DL
docs.text: Your [Stabilization DL] is based on your Resilience score. Resilience of 5 means you have a [Stabilization DL] of Easy (8). Resilience of 4 means you have a [Stabilization DL] of Moderate (14). Resilience of 3 means you have a [Stabilization DL] of Hard (20). Resilience of 2 means you have a [Stabilization DL] of Severe (26). Resilience of 1 means you have a [Stabilization DL] of Extreme (32).

docs.title: Supplies
docs.text: This trick requires materials worth 100 cred (which are consumed upon use)

docs.title: Surgical Procedure
docs.text: An invasive medical procedure, usually performed to treat an injury or install cyberware. A [Surgical Procedure] takes between 30 and 90 minutes from start to finish. As a general rule, a minor procedure takes 30 minutes, a moderate procedure takes 60 minutes, and a major procedure takes 90 minutes.

docs.title: Temporary
docs.text: Some tricks can grant a character a [Temporary] benefit. Once you use the [Temporary] benefit, it is gone. If you end your turn with a [Temporary] benefit, you lose that [Temporary] benefit.

docs.title: Threat
docs.text: [Threat] is an NPC trait that ranges from +1 to +5 and represents an NPC's overall combat capability. The GM adds the NPC's [Threat] bonus to all rolls made for that NPC. An NPC's hit points are equal to their [Threat] x 5.

docs.title: Tools
docs.text: This skill action requires tools worth 200 cred (which are retained upon use).

docs.title: Trick
docs.text: A trick is a specific use of a skill. Each skill includes [[[Keyword_Core_Trick|Core Tricks]]] and [[[Keyword_Signature_Trick|Signature Tricks]]] Core tricks and signature tricks include their own rules and their own outcomes. When a player wants to try something not covered by the rules, the GM can allow it as an [[[Keyword_Improvised_Trick|Improvised Trick]]].

docs.title: Two-Handed Grip
docs.text: Light Pistols and Heavy Pistols can be fired using a [Two-Handed Grip] to improve accuracy. This requires [[[Keyword_Two_Hands|Two Hands]]]. When using [Two-Handed Grip], the DL is lowered by one.

docs.title: Two Hands
docs.text: You must must both hands.

docs.title: Unarmed Strike
docs.text:
Indicates an [[[Keyword_Attack|Attack]]] made without weapons, such as a punch or kick. See the [[[Skills_and_Tricks/Trick_Brawl_Core_Unarmed_Strike|Unarmed Strike]]] trick for more information.

The [[[Keyword_Damage_Array|Damage Array]]] for [Unarmed Strike] uses your Strength score for [[[Keyword_Minimum_Damage|Minimum Damage]]], Strength x 2 for [[[Keyword_Normal_Damage|Normal Damage]]], and Strength x 5 for [[[Keyword_Maximum_Damage|Maximum Damage]]].

docs.title: Upgraded
docs.text: When an [[Making_a_Roll/Outcomes|Outcome]] is [Upgraded], it is improved by one level. That is, a Glitch becomes a Fade, a Fade becomes a Success, and a Success becomes a Cool Success. A Cool Success cannot be [Upgraded].

docs.title: Vehicle
docs.text: This skill or trick requires you to be driving a [Vehicle], such as a car, truck, or motorcycle.

docs.title: Vicinity
docs.text: This trick tracks the proximity of people to one another. Indoors, you and another person are in the same [Vicinity] if you are [[[Keyword_Nearby|Nearby]]], such as in the same a room, hallway, etc. Outdoors, the [Vicinity] is limited to being [[[Keyword_Close|Close]]] to the other person.

docs.title: Visible

docs.title: Adjusting the Difficulty Level
docs.text: Before the roll, the GM should adjust the DL based on relevant conditions, NPC's attitudes, and environmental effects.

docs.title: Raising and Lowering the DL
docs.text:
When you adjust the DL, you move up or down an entire Difficulty Level tier. That is, if the DL is Moderate (14) and something causes the DL to be raised by one, the DL goes to Hard (20) because that is the next step up in the Difficulty Level chart. If the DL is Moderate (14) and something causes it to be lowered, it goes to Easy (8) because that is the next step down in the chart.

Difficulty Level DL Range Extreme (32) 32 - 37 Severe (26) 26 - 31 Hard (20) 20 - 25 Moderate (14) 14 - 19 Easy (8) 8 - 13 These five Difficulty Levels, Easy (8), Moderate (14), Hard (20), Severe (26), and Extreme (32), are the only DLs you will ever use in this game. You will never apply a +1 to a DL causing it to be 9, for example. When a DL is raised or lowered, it moves a full increment up or down the chart.

docs.title: Easy (8) and Extreme (32)
docs.text:
The level below Easy (8) is considered trivial. If the DL is Easy (8) and a trick or effect lowers it, the GM can rule that no roll is necessary because the action is so trivial, it carries no risk. Otherwise, the DL stays at Easy (8).

The level above Extreme (32) is considered impossible. If the DL is Extreme (32) and a trick or effect raises it, the GM can rule that the action is simply not possible for the character. Otherwise, the DL stays at Extreme (32).

docs.title: Conditions
docs.text: Conditions like [[[Condition_Wounded|Wounded]]], [[[Condition_Distracted|Distracted]]], and [[[Condition_Inspired|Inspired]]] raise or lower the DL on rolls you make. Conditions are described in their own section later in this book. If a character is under the effects of multiple conditions that alter the DL, they all apply.

docs.title: Environmental Effects
docs.text: When the environment could negatively influence the outcome of a roll, refer to the appropriate conditions in these rules. Some tricks are more difficult to pull off successfully when it is [[[Condition_Raining|Raining]]], [[[Conditions/Condition_Foggy|Foggy]]], [[[Conditions/Condition_Windy|Windy]]] or [[[Condition_Dark|Dark]]]. To keep things quick, the GM can eschew these specific conditions and decide to simply raise the DL by one anytime there are one or more environmental effects that make a trick more difficult.

docs.title: Attitude
docs.text:
When you use a [[[Keyword_Social|Social]]] trick on an NPC, their [[[Keyword_Attitude|Attitude]]] towards you can raise or lower the DL.

Attitude Effect Friendly Lowers the DL of your [Social] tricks by one Neutral No effect Hostile Raises the DL of your [Social] tricks by one

docs.title: Setting the Difficulty Level
docs.text:
Each trick includes an entry for Difficulty Level (DL), which determines how difficult it is to execute. The DL for a trick is usually a static DL or based on an opponent's traits. Occasionally, a trick eschews the typical DL framework by calling for an [Opposed] roll.

The only time the GM needs to set the DL themselves is when the rules don't cover the action a player wants their character to take. If the GM allows them it, the player can make roll it as an improvised trick, in which case the GM needs to define the DL for the roll.

docs.title: Difficulty Levels
docs.text:
Each Difficulty Level (DL) has a name and a number in parenthesis. When you make a roll, you compare the result (after applying bonuses) to the Difficulty Level to determine the outcome.

A Difficulty Level has a DL range associated with it, as shown below. For example, the DL range for Easy (8) goes from 8 to 13. The next Difficulty Level picks up where the last one stopped, so Moderate (14) goes from 14 to 19, and so on. Rolling above or below the target DL range changes the outcome of your roll, as described under Outcomes below.

There are five Difficulty Levels in this game: Easy (8), Moderate (14), Hard (20), Severe (26), and Extreme (32).

Difficulty Level DL Range Extreme (32) 32 - 37 Severe (26) 26 - 31 Hard (20) 20 - 25 Moderate (14) 14 - 19 Easy (8) 8 - 13

docs.title: Traits as DLs
docs.text:
Some tricks use one of an opponent's trait as the base Difficulty Level. For example, Persuade (Convince) uses your opponent's Wits for the DL and Hacking (Street Hack) uses the [Security] rating of the target device.

Traits are expressed as Difficulty Levels. For example, Rico the food cart vendor has a Wits of Moderate (14), and the local Food Mart's payment system has a [Security] of Hard (20).

docs.title: Static DL
docs.text: Some tricks simply state the DL to use. For example, Insight (Size Up Opponent) has a DL of Moderate (14).

docs.title: Opposed Rolls
docs.text: Occasionally, the rules call for an [Opposed] roll, which means both you and the GM roll (and add your bonuses) and then compare your results to determine the outcome. As such, [Opposed] rolls do not use Difficulty Levels.

docs.title: Improvised Tricks
docs.text: When these rules do not cover the action a player wants their character to perform, the GM can declare it an [[Keyword_Improvised_Trick|improvised trick]]. The GM sets the DL using their best judgement. Refer to the DL chart above and use one of the standard five Difficulty Levels: Easy (8), Moderate (14), Hard (20), Severe (26), and Extreme (32).

docs.title: End of the Action
docs.text: After the outcome of an action has been determined, that action is over. If the player has more action points, they may spend them to do more things. Otherwise, the player's turn is over and the next player's turn starts.

docs.title: Luck Points
docs.text: Luck Points can give you bonuses to your rolls and help you avoid terrible failures, as described below. You start the game with one Luck Point.

docs.title: Buy Luck Points
docs.text: In addition to the Luck Point you get at the start of the game, you can purchase up to two additional Luck Points for 10 XP each. You cannot have more than three Luck Points at any time. Luck Points you purchase are permanent additions to your character. They are spent and recovered as normal.

docs.title: Spending a Luck Point
docs.text:
You can spend a Luck Point in a few ways, as shown below. Once you spend a Luck Point, it is gone for the rest of the game session unless you recover it.

To use a Luck Point you must declare it to the GM and the rest of the group. You must also state how you want to use the Luck Point.

For example, "I'm going to spend a Luck Point to get a bonus on my Firearms roll. I'm using Single Shot. Firearms is one of my Favored Skills, so I get a +3 Luck Bonus."

docs.title: Luck Bonus
docs.text: Before you [[Making_a_Roll|make a roll]], you can spend a Luck Point to get a +2 Luck Bonus to your roll result. If the roll uses one of your Favored Skills, you get a +3 Luck Bonus instead.

docs.title: Avoid a Glitch
docs.text: If you roll a Glitch, you can spend a Luck Point to [[[Keyword_Upgraded|Upgrade]]] the outcome to a Fade.

docs.title: Recovering Luck Points
docs.text: At the start of each game session, your character recovers all of the Luck Points they previously spent. Some tricks and other effects can make you [[[Keyword_Lucky|Lucky]]], which causes you to recover a Luck Point mid-session.

docs.title: Making a Roll
docs.text:
When the GM determines that a roll is necessary, follow the steps below.

  1. Skill - First, identify the skill to use based on what the character is trying to do. For example, use the Firearms skill to shoot a gun and the Athletics skill to make a running jump. If you have a bonus in the selected skill, it is added to your roll.

  2. Ability Score - The skill determines the [[Abilities_and_Ability_Scores|ability score]] to use for the roll. For example, the Firearms skill uses Agility. You will add this ability score to your roll.

  3. Trick - Determine which of the skill's tricks to use. You can use any of the skill's [[Keyword_Core_Trick|core tricks]] or a [[Keyword_Signature_Trick|signature trick]] if you know one that applies.

  4. Difficulty Level - The trick specifies the [[Difficulty_Level|Difficulty Level]] for the roll. The GM adjusts the Difficulty Level up or down, as described in [[Adjusting_the_Difficulty_Level|Adjusting the Difficulty Level]].

  5. Luck Bonus - Before you roll the dice, you can spend a [[Luck_Points|Luck Point]] to get a [[Keyword_Luck_Bonus|luck bonus]] to your roll.

  6. Roll 2d10 - Roll 2d10 (two ten-sided dice) and sum them together. For example, if you rolled a 2 on one die and a 9 on the other die, you would have rolled 11.

  7. Ability Score and Skill Bonus - Add your ability score to the roll. If you have a [[Keyword_Skill_Bonus|skill bonus]] in the skill you're using, add that to the roll too. For example, if you were rolling Firearms with an Agility score of 3 and a +1 skill bonus, you would add +4 to your roll.

  8. Gear and Aug Bonuses - If you have a [[Keyword_Gear_Bonus|gear bonus]] from a piece of equipment or an [[Keyword_Aug_Bonus|aug bonus]] from a cybernetic augmentation or psionic mutation, add those as well. For example, using a laser sight grants a +1 gear bonus to Firearms rolls.

  9. Outcome - Compare the result to the outcomes chart in the description of the trick you used to determine what happens.

Making a Roll 2d10 + [[Abilities_and_Ability_Scores|Ability Score]] + [[Keyword_Skill_Bonus|Skill Bonus]] + [[Keyword_Gear_Bonus|Gear Bonus]] + [[Keyword_Aug_Bonus|Aug Bonus]] + [[Keyword_Luck_Bonus|Luck Bonus]] = Result

docs.title: Stacking Bonuses
docs.text:
For any roll, you add at most one ability score, one skill bonus, one gear bonus, one aug bonus, and one luck bonus. You always add one ability score, but you might not have all (or any) of these bonuses.

Bonuses of the same type that target the same skill do not stack, and only the highest one applies. For example, if you have two pieces of gear that both give a gear bonus to Firearms, only the higher of the two bonuses is applied.

docs.title: Substituting Ability Scores
docs.text:
Even though each skill has its own primary ability, the GM might decide to call for another ability to be used with a skill if it's appropriate.

For example, asking the player to roll Strength with Intimidate when they try to literally strongarm someone into compliance, or having the player roll Drive with Intelligence to see if they know the kind of battery used in a specific model car.

docs.title: Outcomes
docs.text: When you roll for a skill or trick, there are four possible outcomes: Glitch, Fade, Success, and Cool Success.

docs.title: Universal Outcomes
docs.text:
Each trick's specific outcomes chart is modeled after the universal outcomes chart shown below. It shows how to determine if a result is a Glitch, Fade, Success, or Cool Success. The GM should also use this chart to adjudicate improvised tricks when they arise.

For the purpose of determining outcomes, treat the range from 2 - 7 as a Trivial DL and 39+ as an Impossible DL. This framework allows for a Fade on an Easy (8) DL, a Glitch on a Moderate (14) DL, and a Cool Success on an Extreme (32) DL.

Rolling double 10s on 2d10 automatically results in a Cool Success.

Outcome Roll Description Glitch Falls in the DL range two or more levels lower The task failed with a complication Fade Falls in the DL range one level lower The task was completed successfully but with a complication Success Hits the DL range The task was completed successfully Cool Success Over the DL range The task was completed successfully and with an extra benefit

docs.title: Trick Outcomes
docs.text:
When you use a trick included in these rules, you should use the specific outcomes chart included in its description. Each trick has its own outcomes chart but the structure of the four outcomes always follows the universal outcomes shown above. As an example, the outcomes chart for the Persuade (Haggle) signature trick is shown below.

Outcome Description Glitch You get 20% worse price and their [Attitude] worsens Fade You get 20% better price and their [Attitude] worsens Success You get 20% better price Cool Success You get 20% better price and a [Gift]

For example, a player rolls Persuade (Haggle) with a DL of Moderate (14). After applying bonuses, their roll results in a 15. This is a Success because the result falls inside the DL range for Moderate (14), which is 14-19.

docs.title: Opposed Outcomes
docs.text:
When the rules call for an [Opposed] roll (or when the GM decides an [Opposed] roll is appropriate), you and the GM both roll, add your bonuses, and compare results. Tricks that use [Opposed] rolls have their own specific outcomes. When the GM declares an action to be an improvised trick, they should refer to the chart below to determine the outcome of the contest.

Outcome Roll Description Glitch Lower than the GM's roll The task failed with a complication Fade Equals the GM's roll The task was completed successfully but with a complication Success 1-5 higher than the GM's roll The task was completed successfully Cool Success 6+ higher than the GM's roll The task was completed successfully and with an extra benefit For example, a player wants their character to use Brawl (Grapple) on an opponent. This is an [Opposed] roll, so both the GM and the player roll. After applying their bonuses, the GM's result is 9 and the player's result is 12. This is a Success because 12 is 1-5 higher than the GM's result which was 9.

docs.title: Roll 2d10
docs.text:
After you and the GM finish adjusting the DL, you roll a 2d10 (two ten-sided dice) and add the appropriate ability score along with any bonuses to get the result.

Making a roll... 2d10 + Ability Score + Skill Bonus + Gear Bonus + Aug Bonus + Luck Bonus = Result

docs.title: When to Roll
docs.text:
When a player describes what their character is doing, the GM first determines if a roll is necessary. If the task is trivial, impossible, or carries no risk, such that a character could keep trying until they were successful, then it is not necessary to roll.

Task Resolution Examples Trivial You succeed Open a doorMake a phone callLog on to the Net Impossible You cannot attempt Jump over a houseRun across waterAccess cyberspace without jacking in No Risk Keep trying until you succeed Climb over a small fenceNavigate to an unfamiliar destinationRepair a piece of broken equipment

It's important to realize that the same task can be performed automatically when there is no risk but requires a roll when there is. For example, climbing over a small fence is relatively easy to do but still requires some effort.

All else being equal, a character could keep trying until they succeed; no need to roll. However, that same task requires a roll if we introduce risk. For example, a character is being chased and rounds the corner to see a small fence blocking their path. Now if the character decides to go over the fence, the GM should have the player roll, even if the task is easy, because failure leads to consequences (the pursuers catch up).

docs.title: Intimidate [Skill]
docs.text:
Difficulty Level (DL) Ability Keywords [[Keyword_Fort|Fort]] Presence [[[Keyword_Language|Language]]], [[[Keyword_Social|Social]]], [[[Keyword_Vocal|Vocal]]]

With threats of damage to income, reputation, or bodily health, you force the targe to comply with your instructions.

If your instructions put the target in harm's way, the DL is raised by one. The target will refuse to follow suicidal instructions.

docs.title: Persuade [Skill]
docs.text:
Difficulty Level (DL) Ability Keywords Wits Presence [Attitude], [[[Keyword_Language|Language]]], [[[Keyword_Social|Social]]], [[[Keyword_Vocal|Vocal]]]

Using charm and a bit of psychology, you convince the target to help you, typically without offering anything in return.

If your request is unreasonable, the DL is raised by one. The target will refuse truly outrageous requests.

docs.title: Skills and Tricks
docs.text:
There are fifteen skills in this game, three for each of the core five [[Abilities_and_Ability_Scores|abilities]] (Presence, Awareness, Agility, Intelligence, and Strength). For example, the three skills associated with Agility are Drive, Firearms, and Stealth.

If your character knows a skill, it will have a [[Keyword_Skill_Bonus|skill bonus]] ranging from +1 to +3. When you [[Making_a_Roll|make a roll]] with a skill, you add your skill bonus and the skill's primary ability score to the roll.

The skills in this game include rules for [[Keyword_Trick|tricks]], which are specific uses of a skill. For example, the Medicine skill includes a trick called First Aid and another called Surgery.

Tricks are categorized as being either [[Keyword_Core_Trick|core tricks]] or [[Keyword_Signature_Trick|signature tricks]]. Anyone may use core tricks, even if they have no skill bonus, but you can only use a signature trick if your character knows it.

When a player wants to try something not covered by the rules, the GM can allow them to perform an [[Keyword_Improvised_Trick|improvised trick]].

Refer to the [[Skills_and_Tricks/Skills_and_Tricks_List|Skills and Tricks List]] for a full list of skills and tricks included in this game.

docs.title: Acrobatic Stunt [Signature Trick]
docs.text:
Difficulty Level (DL) Skill Keywords Hard (20) Athletics [[[Keyword_Move|Move]]], [[[Keyword_Physical|Physical]]], [[[Keyword_Visual|Visual]]]

You utilize your incredible balance and speed to execute a death defying climb, jump, or dive.

Use Acrobatic Stunt to [[[Keyword_Move|Move]]] beyond a significant physical obstacle or to gain access to a hard-to-reach area. When you use this trick, state the desired outcome of your [Move], such as I want to move across the wire like a tightrope walker or I want to scale the sheer surface of this building.

Outcome Description Glitch You do not [[[Keyword_Move|Move]]] and you are [[[Condition_Off_Balance|Off Balance]]] Fade You [Move] as desired but you are [Off Balance] Success You [Move] as desired Cool Success You [Move] as desired and you are [[[Condition_Inspired|Inspired]]]

docs.title: Athletic Move [Core Trick]
docs.text:
Difficulty Level (DL) Skill Keywords Moderate (14) Athletics [[[Keyword_Move|Move]]], [[[Keyword_Physical|Physical]]], [[[Keyword_Visual|Visual]]], ([[[Keyword_Two_Hands|Two Hands]]])

You engage in a physical activity like climbing, jumping, or swimming.

Athletic Move is used to [[[Keyword_Move|Move]]] by climbing, jumping, or swimming, When you use Physical Activity, state the desired outcome of your [Move], such as I want to climb over the fence or I want jump from this rooftop to the next one. If the desired outcome is unlikely, raise the DL by one, and if it is highly unlikely, raise the DL by two.

Outcome Description Glitch You fall [[[Condition_Prone|Prone]]] and may take falling damage (GM discretion) Fade You get the desired outcome but you are [[[Condition_Off_Balance|Off Balance]]] Success You get the desired outcome Cool Success You get the desired outcome and recover 1 AP

docs.title: Catch [Core Trick]
docs.text:
Difficulty Level (DL) Skill Keywords Moderate (14) Athletics [[[Keyword_Two_Hands|Two Hands]]], [[[Keyword_Physical|Physical]]], [[[Keyword_Range|Range]]], [[[Keyword_Visual|Visual]]]

You catch an object as it's falling or that was thrown to you.

When an object is thrown to you or falls [[[Keyword_Close|Close]]] to you, you can use a [[[Keyword_Reaction|Reaction]]] to Catch it. If you use only [[[Keyword_One_Hand|One Hand]]], raise the DL by one. If the object is difficult to catch due to its size, weight, or other factors, the GM may raise the DL by one or simply state that it is not possible.

Outcome Description Glitch You miss and are [[[Condition_Off_Balance|Off Balance]]] Fade You catch the object and are [Off Balance] Success You catch the object Cool Success You catch the object and are [[[Condition_Inspired|Inspired]]]

docs.title: Sprint [Core Trick]
docs.text:
Difficulty Level (DL) Skill Keywords Moderate (14) Athletics [[[Keyword_Move|Move]]], [[[Keyword_Physical|Physical]]], [[[Keyword_Range|Range]]], [[[Keyword_Visual|Visual]]]

You take off in a beeline, putting all your energy into running as fast as you can.

When you use Sprint, you must [[[Keyword_Move|Move]]] in a straight line.

Outcome Description Glitch You [[[Keyword_Move|Move]]] [[[Keyword_Nearby|Nearby]]] and are [[[Condition_Off_Balance|Off Balance]]] Fade You [Move] [[[Keyword_Far|Far]]] and are [Off Balance] Success You [Move] [Far] Cool Success You [Move] [Far] and recover 1 AP

docs.title: Throw [Core Trick]
docs.text:
Difficulty Level (DL) Skill Keywords Moderate (14) Athletics [[[Keyword_One_Hand|One Hand]]], [[[Keyword_Physical|Physical]]], [[[Keyword_Range|Range]]], [[[Keyword_Visual|Visual]]]

You throw an object and hit your mark.

To use Throw, identify the mark, the spot where you want the object to land or the person you are throwing to. If the mark is [[[Keyword_Far|Far]]] away, raise the DL by one. If the object cannot be thrown effectively due to its weight, size, or other factors. the GM may raise the DL by one, tell the player they can only throw the object [[[Keyword_Close|Close]]] or [[[Keyword_Nearby|Nearby]]], or simply state that it is not possible.

Outcome Description Glitch You miss the mark and are [[[Condition_Off_Balance|Off Balance]]] Fade You hit the mark and are [Off Balance] Success You hit the mark Cool Success You hit the mark and are [[[Condition_Inspired|Inspired]]]

docs.title: Forced Move [Core Trick]
docs.text:
Difficulty Level (DL) Skill Keywords [[[Keyword_Opposed|Opposed]]] Brawl [[[Keyword_Attack|Attack]]], [[[Keyword_Move|Move]]], [[[Keyword_Physical|Physical]]], [[[Keyword_Range|Range]]], [[[Keyword_Visual|Visual]]]

You grab your opponent and force them to move with your superior ability.

To use Forced Move, your opponent must be [[[Keyword_Close|Close]]]. If they are [[[Condition_Restrained|Restrained]]], your Forced Move outcome is [[[Keyword_Upgraded|Upgraded]]].

Outcome Description Glitch You fail and are [[[Condition_Off_Balance|Off Balance]]] Fade You force them to [[[Keyword_Move|Move]]] and you are [Off Balance] Success You force them to [Move] Cool Success You force them to [Move] and put them in [[[Condition_Agony|Agony]]] if desired

docs.title: Grapple [Core Trick]
docs.text:
Without this trick,

Difficulty Level (DL) Skill Keywords [[[Keyword_Opposed|Opposed]]] Brawl [[[Keyword_Attack|Attack]]], [[[Keyword_Move|Move]]], [[[Keyword_Physical|Physical]]], [[[Keyword_Range|Range]]], [[[Keyword_Visual|Visual]]]

You run after your opponent, grabbing them and tacking them to the ground.

When you use Grapple, [[[Keyword_Move|Move]]] to an opponent who is [[[Keyword_Close|Close]]] or [[[Keyword_Nearby|Nearby]]] and then roll Grapple.

Outcome Description Glitch You are [[[Condition_Restrained|Restrained]]] and you are both [[[Condition_Prone|Prone]]] Fade They are [Restrained] and you are both [Prone] Success They are [Restrained] and [Prone] Cool Success They are [Restrained], [Prone] and [[[Condition_Shaken|Shaken]]]
